item.title: Federal judge dismisses states' suit over SALT tax deductions---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ywang
item.content:encoded:
United States District Court for the Southern District of New York on Monday dismissed a suit against the Trump administration brought by four states: New York, Connecticut, Maryland and New Jersey. The legislation at issue is Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, signed into law in December 2017, which made several substantial amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act created an upper limit on the amount a taxpayer may deduct from his or her federally taxable income to offset those sums he or she has paid toward certain state and local taxes (the “SALT cap”). The states filed a suit alleging that the SALT cap violates the federalism principles that undergird the U.S. Constitution. After the Act's enactment in 2017, although a taxpayer may continue to claim a federal tax deduction for state and local real and personal property taxes and state and local income taxes or state and local sales taxes, these claimed deductions could not total any more than $10,000 for single or jointly filing married taxpayers or any more than $5,000 for a married taxpayer filing separately.
The Court found that by plausibly alleging that the SALT cap will decrease their real estate transfer tax revenues and that this injury can be redressed through the declaratory and injunctive relief, they established standing. The Court also found that the case is not a political question, because it "asks this Court to use familiar tools of constitutional interpretation to decide whether a specific statute oversteps the bounds of federal authority."
While acknowledging that the SALT cap is unprecedented, the Court held that there is no constitutional principle "that would bar Congress from exercising its otherwise plenary power to impose an income tax without a limitless SALT deduction." On the states' theory of coercion, the Court held that "an otherwise valid federal law does not offend the Constitution simply because it seeks to affect state policies", and therefore refused to inquire into Congress's motive in acting to exercise its constitutionally conferred power.

item.title: Judge rules jury may consider Castle Doctrine in case of woman entering wrong apartment and shooting unarmed black man---HOLD
item.dc:creator: mborges
item.content:encoded: Judge Tammy Kemp, in Dallas County District Court, ruled on Monday to allow the jury to consider the Castle Doctrine in the case of Amber Guyger. Guyger is a Dallas police officer who, in 2018, mistakenly entered the apartment one floor above hers and fatally shot Botham Jean in his home. The jury found Guyger guilty of murder on Tuesday which could carry a sentence of life in prison. Guyger had just come off a 14-hour shift and was still in uniform, she later tested negative for drugs and alcohol. Jean was sitting on his couch watching TV when she entered and mistook him for a burglar. There are differing accounts on where Jean was in the apartment when he was shot. Additionally, the facts show that she heard movement inside and decided to engage instead of calling for backup. The jury will consider the charges of murder or manslaughter. Texas' Castle Doctrine law provides that one does not have a duty to retreat in their own home when protecting themselves against an intruder. Via a Mistake of Fact defense, where Guyger reasonably believed that she was entering her own apartment, the Castle Doctrine could apply. Despite objections from the state, the Judge ruled to let the jury consider it. It is important to note here that, even though the Castle Doctrine is available to the jury, they must still first decide whether Guyger had a reasonable belief that she was in her own apartment at the time of the shooting. The Judge did not rule that Guyger had that reasonable belief, just that the jury is entitled to use the doctrine once they make that decision. It is speculated that a conviction with the Castle Doctrine available is less likely to be overturned later for error.

item.title: EU High Court forces Facebook to remove content---HOLD
item.dc:creator: bbell
item.content:encoded: Eva Glawischnig-Piesczek, a politician in Austria, sued Facebook Ireland for the removal of a posted comment that she felt was harmful to her reputation. The case rose to the Supreme Court of Austria who asked the Court of Justice (the highest court in the European Union) to interpret the directive on electronic commerce. The EU Court  determined that countries in the European Union are permitted to "[order] a host provider [like Facebook] to remove information which it stores, the content of which is identical to the content of information which was previously declared to be unlawful, or to block access to that information..." The court clarified that this is "limited to information conveying a message the content of which remains essentially unchanged compared with the content that gave rise to the finding of illegality." The host state may order a host provider to "remove information covered by the injunction or to block access to that information worldwide within the framework of the relevant international law." Thomas Hughes, the Executive Director of Article 19, a UK charity group that campaigns to make social media companies transparent said: "Compelling social media platforms like Facebook to automatically remove posts regardless of their context will infringe our right to free speech and restrict the information we see online. The judgment does not take into account the limitations of technology when it comes to automated filters." This ruling is the latest in the international trend of countries regulating and restricting Facebook as a platform.

item.title: Federal judge rules supervised injection sites do not violate drug laws---HOLD
item.dc:creator: bbell
item.content:encoded: Safehouse, a nonprofit in Philadelphia, seeks to open an "overdose prevention site" that will offer a variety of services, including the use of medically supervised consumption and observation rooms for patients. The government sought to block the site, arguing that consumption rooms violate 21 U.S.C. Section 856(a)(2) forbidding drug-involved premises. U.S. District Judge Gerald A. McHugh determined that Safehouse does not intend to operate the site for "an unlawful purpose" of illegal drug use and discusses the legislative history. He writes that Congress when approving the legislation could not have foreseen the opioid epidemic health crisis. Furthermore, Safehouse does not make the facility available for the "purpose of" facilitating illegal drug use. "To read Section 856(a)(2) to apply to medical purposes and effort to combat drug abuse would take the statute well beyond what it aimed to criminalize." The Deputy Attorney General responded: “The Department is disappointed in the Court’s ruling and will take all available steps to pursue further judicial review.  Any attempt to open illicit drug injection sites in other jurisdictions while this case is pending will continue to be met with immediate action by the Department.” "Philadelphia is being devastated. We've lost about three people a day [to opioid overdoses]....we couldn't sit back and let that death toll rise. And the court agreed with us," said Ronda Goldfein, Safehouse's Vice President and Secretary.

item.title: TEST Federal Judge Rejects President Trump's Immunity Claim---PENDING
item.dc:creator: tgillett
item.content:encoded: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York dismissed a lawsuit brought by President Trump to prevent a subpeona from the Manhattan District Attorney's office requesting the president's tax returns for the past eight years. The suit claimed that the president is not simply immune to criminal prosecution while in office, but immune to the criminal process altogether, including investigation and grand jury proceedings. The suit is in response to the district attorney's investigation of claims of payments made in relation to affairs the president is alleged to have had. The court noted the Constitution's relative silence about the scope and extent of presidential immunity, a silence the president sought to fill with his lawsuit claiming, in the court's terms, a "presidential shield" which would cover not just the president's activities while in office, but extend to shielding him from investigation for possible wrong-doing prior to taking office. The court also found that the immunity claim would derivatively cover any person, associate, relative, or business affiliate which may have collaborated in possible wrong-doing. Since this shield would protect the president until he left office (either through term limits, resignation, or impeachment and conviction), the court stated concern that any delay in beginning criminal investigation could lead to statutes of limitations running out, especially in light of the retroactive protection this shield would confer upon the president himself as well as any and all associates who might be implicated in prior criminal activity. The court categorically rejected this argument, noting it had "fundamental concerns" over the aggregation of power to the executive to the severe detriment of the other two branches, as well as upsetting the balance between federal and state authority. The court concluded that the president's theory of presidential immunity is "repugnant to the nation's governmental structure and constitutional values," dismissing the suit and further denying the president's motion for injunctive relief.

item.title: TEST -- Judge dismisses Trump's lawsuit to block subpoena -- PENDING
item.dc:creator: gwast
item.content:encoded: On Monday, October 7th, Judge Marrero of the US District Court for the Southern District of New York dismissed President Donald Trump's complaint against the Manhattan District Attorney. The judge stated that the President is not immune from compliance with a grand jury subpoena the District Attorney served to Mazars USA in August. Mazars was the accounting firm that filed the tax returns of the Trump Organization that the District Attorney is requesting. The President sought injunctive relief from the court to prevent the District Attorney from accessing the tax returns. The District Attorney argued that the federal government may not interfere with the criminal investigations of a state government. The judge stated that the President's proclaimed immunity is an overreach of presidential power that would shield not only the president but any of his associates that may have committed unlawful acts. He explained that it would be unjust to put off the investigation until the President is out of office just because what is found could be incriminating. The judge also pointed to the fact that the Constitution does not comment on presidential immunity from criminal processes. The judge held that President Trump must adhere to the grand jury subpoena and the District Attorney's investigation that relates to transactions possibly associated with the President prior to his taking office.

item.title: TEST - Court rejects absolute immunity claim
item.dc:creator: ebeeken
item.content:encoded: The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York rejected President Donald Trump's claim of absolute immunity from the judicial process, fearing the reach of this claim. The Manhattan District Attorney subpoenaed Trump's accountants, seeking eight years of tax returns. Trump's attorneys sought an injunction against the subpoena, claiming irreparable harm, and that "it is clear," that no state can, "criminally investigate, prosecute, or indict a President while in office." The Court called Trump's claim "repugnant to the nation's governmental structure and Constitutional values." The Court "denied the President's motion for injunctive relief" from the subpoena, and refused to adjudicate the dispute. Trump's claim would cast a wide net of immunity upon him, relatives, associates, and business affiliates. Under Trump's claim, the statute of limitations would continue to run while investigations are prohibited. It would cover not only his actions in office, but also his actions before his tenure. item.title: Test --- Draft Pending
item.dc:creator: zgujral
item.content:encoded: On October 7, 2019, United States District Judge Victor Marrero dismissed President Trump's law suit to block a subpoena issued by the Manhattan District Attorney's office for eight years of his tax returns. Mr. Trump claims that he is entitled to immunity because States cannot criminally investigate, prosecute or indict a sitting president. He further claims that he will suffer "irreparable harm" if he is forced to comply with the subpoena. Mr. Trump has been fighting to prevent access to his tax returns for several years, and obtained a temporary injunction against California's Presidential Tax Transparency and Accountability Act on September 20, 2019. Judge Marrero ruled that Mr. Trump had failed to provide sufficient evidence that the subpoena would harm him as the District Attorney and Grand Juries are under legal obligations to maintain confidentiality. Judge Marrero goes on to refute Mr. Trump's claim of immunity. According to Judge Marrero, third parties can be "subpoenaed requesting documents related to an investigation concerning potentially unlawful transactions and conduct of third parties in which records possessed or controlled by the sitting President may be critical to establish the guilt or innocence of such third parties, or of the President." Additionally, according to Judge Marrero, the issue of whether or not sitting Presidents have immunity from criminal proceedings has not be decided either way, and memorandum from the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel is insufficient to establish that President's cannot be held criminally liable. While Mr. Trump points to documents supporting his claim of immunity from Counsels to past Presidents, Judge Marrero is not convinced that they should have the legal weight Mr. Trump would ascribe to them. Further, the Supreme Court has ruled on a number of occasions that under certain circumstances a sitting President can be subjected to the judicial process. Click here to see the full text of Judge Marrero's decision.

item.title: TEST- Federal Judge Dismisses Trump's Suit to Block Tax Return Injunctions- PENDING
item.dc:creator: vnegron
item.content:encoded: President Trump's suit to block the New York injunction to subpoena his tax returns has been dismissed. A federal judge has dismissed the suit saying, "This Court cannot endorse such a categorical and limitless assertion of presidential immunity from judicial process as being countenanced by the nation' s constitutional plan." The court goes on to argue that allowing the suit would be totally against the separation of powers. President Trump's suit sought to protect his business associates and himself from all court proceedings while he serves as President. This would include all transactions including those that happened before he was President of the United States. The suit delves into the immunity that President Trump is seeking and states that it is on the broader end of the spectrum which is outside the view typically held by the court. The court will usually only grant immunity in matters that have to do with the office of the President and not the president as a private citizen. For now, the court holds that their position has not changed and the suit will not be allowed to move forward.

item.title: Test- Federal Judge dismisses President Trump's tax return lawsuit -Draft
item.dc:creator: jcossin
item.content:encoded: On Monday, a Federal Judge for the Southern District of New York dismissed the President's lawsuit requesting an injunction against a subpoena filed by Manhattans District Attorney seeking the last 8 years of the President's tax returns. The judge called the President's definition of presidential immunity "extraordinary" and stated that it would allow the president "absolute immunity from criminal process of any kind." President Trump has sought to keep his tax returns confidential since his time as a mere candidate. Attempts to see these tax returns have taken a number of different forms including several efforts in the House of Representatives. Many Democrats have voiced concerns that beyond the generally accepted rationale for elected officials to publish tax returns that the President may be hiding specific criminal conduct or conflict of interests from the public. More specifically, they allege that the President paid hush money to Stormy Daniels before the election and that there may be evidence of collusion with Russia. Republicans have generally viewed these requests as part of an ongoing witch hunt against the President by the democratic party. The case stems from a subpoena issued by the Manhattan district attorney towards the end of August. It sought Federal and State tax returns from the president and his copy going back to 2011. The subpoena was issued on the grounds that the tax returns contain information relevant to a number of ongoing investigations in the state of New York. Primarily the subpoena is aimed at determining if the company falsely accounted for reimbursements as a legal expense. Such an act could constitute a felony if it was committed to conceal another crime. After the case was dismissed the President appealed to the US Court of Appeals 2nd Circuit. The Court has granted him a temporary injunction blocking the president's accounting firm from needing to immediately hand over the tax returns while the case is pending an expedited review process.

item.title: TEST - "Faithless Electors" Ask Court to Take Up Case---PENDING
item.dc:creator: tgillett
item.content:encoded: Three presidential electors have asked the U.S. Supreme Court to take up the appeal of their conviction under a state law that fines electors who vote contrary to their party's nominee. Peter Chiafalo, Levi Guerra, and Esther John were presidential electors for the Washington State Democratic party during the 2016 presidential election. At the time, Washington had a statute that required electors to cast their votes for the persons nominated by their party or face a $1000 fine. Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine won the state, but when it came time to cast their electoral votes, all three voted Colin Powell for president, and split their vice-presidential votes among Maria Cantwell, Susan Collins, and Elizabeth Warren. They were subsequently fined by the Washington Secretary of State for failing to vote for the nominees of their party. The three electors would like the Supreme Court to hear their case, because of what they believe is the pressing nature of this issue with regard to future presidential elections. They note that the 2000 election was decided by just five electoral votes, and there were a total of seven so-called "faithless electors" who voted contrary to their party in 2016. Two months after the Washington Supreme Court upheld their fines, the Tenth Circuit heard a similar case from Colorado; in that case, the elector, who cast his vote for John Kasich rather than Clinton, had his vote discarded as a result of a Colorado law. The Tenth Circuit found the Colorado law violated that elector's right to cast his electoral vote at his discretion. The current petitioners urge the Court to take up their case and resolve the conflict between the Washington Court and the Tenth Circuit decisions before the next election.

item.title: Test --- Draft 2
item.dc:creator: zgujral
item.content:encoded:
On October 7, 2019, the three Washington state Electors submitted a petition for a writ of certioari. The Electors, Peter Bret Chiafalo, Levi Jennet Guerra and Esther Virginia John, voted for Colin Powell, instead of Hilary Clinton, who had won the State's popular vote. Under Washington state law Presidential Electors must vote for who ever won the state's popular vote, and failure to do so will result in a fine. The Electors lost the lower court battles, and seek review by the Supreme Court. The Electors claim that the law is unconstitutional because "(1) a State has now power to legally enforce how a presidential elector casts his or her ballot; and (2) a State penalizing an elector for exercising his or her constitutional discretion to vote violates the First Amendment."
Additionally, the Electors argue that the Washington Supreme Court's decision is at odds with a ruling by the Tenth Circuit that Electors have the Constitutional right to vote for whoever they wish. The Tenth Circuit's ruling came out two months after the Washington Supreme Court made its decision.

item.title: Jury awards Sandy Hook parent $450,000 in defamation lawsuit
item.dc:creator: bbell
item.content:encoded: A Wisconsin jury on Tuesday awarded a parent of a child killed during the Sandy Hook Massacre $450,000 in damages against conspiracy theorists. William Pozner's six-year-old son, Noah Pozner was killed at his elementary school in December 2012. A summary judgment found in June that James Fetzer and Mike Palecek defamed Pozner with statements that the shooting was government conspiracy and that Noah Pozner did not die. According to the complaint, Fetzer, a retired University of Minnesota Duluth professor, wrote a 2016 book, "Nobody Died At Sandy Hook" and circulated a forgery of the child's death certificate. Palecek is the editor of the book and co-founder of the book's publishing company. Pozner claims he relocated several times due to death threats fueled by the conspiracy theorists. Pozner has created a non-profit organization, HONR, in honor of his son, with the aim of ending harassment of mass tragedy victims' families. Pozner released a statement saying: "This [decision] is a victory for truth and decency. Today marks an important turning point for victims of hoaxers and online harassers. Unimpeded, conspiracy theories distort truth and erase history. They dehumanize victims. They manipulate the public."

item.title: TEST- EU's highest court rules Polish law to lower retirement age was in breach of EU equality laws.
item.dc:creator: tmohamed
item.content:encoded:
The European Court of Justice (ECJ) ruled last Tuesday that Poland's 2017 policy, to lower the retirement age unequally between the genders, was in breach of EU equality laws under Article 157 TFEU. In an attempt to reform the judiciary, the Sąd Najwyższy (Polish Supreme Court) introduced a new retirement age for judges and public prosecutors from 67 for both men and women to 65 and 60 years old respectively. The amended law resulted in many members of the judiciary facing early retirement, which raised legal issues by the European Commission. Following the judgment, the ECJ declared that amended law was first contrary to Directive 2006/38, as it constituted a 'measure of positive discrimination'. The access to pensions was unequal by both gender and the additional 'period of service' condition (which came from reducing the age of retirement). Recital 14 states:
"...the pension scheme concerns a particular category of workers and its benefits are directly related to the period of service and calculated by reference to the public servant’s final salary. For reasons of clarity, it is, therefore, appropriate to make specific provision to that effect."
The second strand of the judgment made a more direct attempt at intervening with the increasing power of the executive over the judiciary. The ECJ declared that the Minister for Justice was no longer entitled to make provisions over the retirement age of judges, for example, the ability to carry out their duties after the retirement act. This responsibility was shifted to the National Council of the Judiciary for Poland [42]. This important power shift will be key to protecting judicial independence in Poland. It was declared that it was correct for the European Commission's to intervene with national 'legal protection', to ensure that EU law is upheld by independent judicial entities, in accordance with Article 19(1) TEU and Article 47 of the Charter.  The final judgment was to prevent a reformed system forcing judges into retirement by decisions made unfairly by the minister. The Commission stated:
"...that preservation of the independence of bodies such as the ordinary Polish courts, which are entrusted, inter alia, with the task of interpreting and applying EU law, must be guaranteed."

item.title: Maldives lawmakers remove two high court judges
item.dc:creator: emccarthy
item.content:encoded: Legislators in the Maldives voted on Monday to impeach two judges on its Supreme Court: its Chief Judge Dr. Ahmed Abdulla Didi and Judge Uz. Adam Mohamed Abdulla. 69 ruling party lawmakers voted to remove both judges, well above the two-thirds majority needed in the 87-member house.

item.title: UN Environment Program releases bleak report on temperature change projections based on global carbon emissions rates
item.dc:creator: amauroni
item.content:encoded: The UN Environment Program has released its tenth annual report on emissions gaps, having found that the current rate of global carbon emissions will lead to an average temperature rise of 3.5 degrees Celsius over preindustrial levels by 2100. The report is completed by international scientists and specialists that assess where countries are in terms of their emissions levels versus where they need to be to avoid the worst damage from climate change.

item.title: TEST Federal judge dismisses Trump's complaint asserting absolute presidential immunity from criminal processes
item.dc:creator: vbesteman
item.content:encoded: A federal judge dismissed Monday President Donald Trump's complaint asserting "absolute immunity from criminal processes of any kind." This action comes following a subpoena issued by the Manhattan district attorney's office for eight years of the President's tax returns. Trump's complaint rests largely on his view of presidential duties and functions as well as the separation of executive and judicial powers under the United States Constitution. He contends that these duties, functions, and allocations render the person who serves as President immune from criminal processes during their time in office. These proceedings span from investigations to incarceration and encompass any conduct at either the federal or state level, with or without other individuals. The implications of the President's argument, as acknowledged by the court, are far-reaching. A presidential shield from judicial processes would extend to matters arising from the President's performance in his official role as well as private matters, financial transactions, and any other conduct of an ordinary citizen. The shield would theoretically be in effect until the end of the President's term, his resignation, or his removal through impeachment and conviction. The court held that the "categorical and limitless assertion of presidential immunity" argued for by Trump would constitute "an overreach of executive power." Though the court recognizes that subjecting the President to criminal proceedings may, in some instances, interfere with his ability to carry out constitutional functions, it suggests that such consequences would not necessarily follow every stage of every criminal proceeding. Compliance with a grand jury subpoena on tax returns, for instance, would not necessarily hinder the President's ability to uphold his executive duties and functions. The court also recognizes Constitutional silence on absolute presidential immunity from judicial proceedings as well as the reluctance of past courts to rule in favor of such claims for immunity.

item.title: TEST-President Trump's unconstitutional attempt at avoiding prosecution
item.dc:creator: enapoleon
item.content:encoded:
On Monday, October 7, a New York federal judge dismissed Donald Trump's claims to prevent the release of his tax returns. The District Attorney of New York initially subpoenaed President Trump for various documents and records from June 2015 through September 2018, relating to the Trump Organization, LLC. A subsequent subpoena, known as the Mazars Subpoena, was served on August 29, 2010. This document sought out the tax returns of the President and potential third parties from January 2011 through the present. In attempt to prevent compliance with the subpoena and disclosure of his tax returns, the President filed suit in the Unites States District Court of the Southern District of New York. In his claim, President Trump asserted that the presidency shielded him from the criminal process, including investigations, subpoena, indictment, prosecution and arrest. The court denied this claim, relying on previous court rulings. These previous rulings have held that presidential immunity does not extend to civil suits related to conduct prior to raking office, responding to subpoenas involving the conduct of third persons, and providing testimony in relation to that conduct of a third person. In addition, the court specifically focuses on how the President's interpretation of his immunity would infringe on the separation of powers as allotted by the United States Constitution. Judge Marrero states,
"This Court cannot endorse such a categorical and limitless assertion of presidential immunity from judicial process as being countenanced by the nations' constitutional plan, especially in light of the fundamental concerns over excessive arrogation of power that animated the Constitution's delicate structure and its calibrated balance of authority among the three branches of the national government, as well as between federal and state authorities."
President Trump's view of his immunity from the judicial process when in office presents the question: can an individual rise above the law while sitting in office? It is clear that the Founders did not intend the President to remain untouchable from the law while in office, thus the court denies this contention and forces President Trump to comply with the subpoenas.

item.title: Test - President Trump's lawsuit dismissed by US District Court----PENDING
item.dc:creator: jlamp
item.content:encoded: After Donald Trump was awarded a brief delay in subpoena actions granted on Sept. 19, the U.S. District Court of Southern New York dismissed his request to enjoin a subpoena seeking records and documents, including tax records, from Mazars USA for the period from January 2011 to the present. Trump's arguments attempted to create a categorical imperative in which presidential immunity extends to all areas of conduct and includes actions while in office as well as actions occurring prior to the taking of office. District Court Judge Victor Marrero states in the opinion: "The Court rejects the President's theory because, as articulated, such sweeping doctrine finds no support in the Constitution's text or history, or in germane guidance charted by rulings of the United States Supreme Court." The District Court argues that precedent has established the president as both the head of the country and a private citizen, and immunity does not shield a president from actions occurring before becoming president. Among other things, the Court found that if the presidential immunity Trump seeks is granted, it could lead to a suppression of investigation into third parties' potential crimes if there is reason to believe it would also uncover evidence against a sitting president.  "In that instance, the President's claim of absolute immunity conceivably could enable the guilty to go free , and deprive the innocent of an opportunity to resolve serious accusations in a court of law." At pg. 62.  It could also exhaust a statute of limitations during the period under which the president would be immune to investigation. While recognizing presidential immunity for actions taken in an official capacity and within the scope of the office, the court rejected categorical immunity for a sitting president. Citing court precedent, the court rejects and interpretation "that would 'sustain an absolute, unqualified Presidential privilege of immunity from judicial process under all circumstances.'" At pg. 70.

item.title: Test--- United States District Court dismissed President Trump's lawsuit to block tax return subpoena ---review
item.dc:creator: rsalamacha
item.content:encoded: Today, the United States District Court in the Southern District of New York dismissed President Donald Trump's lawsuit to the block a grand jury subpoena. The president filed suit this September to block the Manhattan District Attorney's subpoena of eight years worth of state and federal tax returns from the president's accountants. The president's lawyers filed the motion to block the subpoena on the grounds that the president is immune from any criminal proceedings during his term.  The president argued that his immunity from the judicial process derives from constitutional separation of powers. Judge Marrero, the District Court judge who presided over the case, conceded in his opinion "that subjecting the President to some aspects of criminal proceedings could impermissibly interfere with or even incapacitate the President 's ability to discharge constitutional functions."  Despite this concession, Judge Marrero still dismissed the suit, finding that not all aspects of criminal proceedings against the president impede presidential duties.  Instead, Judge Marrero found the president's arguement in this case excessive.  According to Marrero, the president's interpretation of immunity "would encompass any [criminal] conduct, at any time , in any forum whether federal or state, and whether the President acted alone or in concert with other individuals."  The court refused to endorse such a broad application of presidential judicial immunity.  Instead, it favored immunity only when the president was acting in accordance to his officail duties.  The court found immuniy inappropriate for personal matters, and therefore, found the dismissal of the suit appropriate.

item.title: TEST - U.S. District Court rejects Trump's "categorical and limitless assertion of presidential immunity" in response to tax returns subpoena ---PENDING
item.dc:creator: amauroni
item.content:encoded:
The Southern District of New York's federal court has denied President Trump's motion to dismiss the subpoena filed by New York District Attorney Cyrus R . Vance, Jr. in relation to his investigation of actions by the Trump Organization in New York. Trump's motion to dismiss this case was contingent upon the claim that sitting presidents have the privilege of immunity from the criminal process. District Court Judge Victor Marrero rejected this motion, which he understood to "stretch to cover every phase of criminal proceedings". The District Judge stated that this could interfere with investigations into illegal actions taken by the President or those close to him either before or during his presidency:
"[T]he record before the Court indicates that the District Attorney is investigating a set of facts, and a number of individuals and business entities, in relation to which conduct by the President, lawful or unlawful, may or may not be a part. Accordingly, the question before the Court narrows to whether the District Attorney may issue a grand jury subpoena to a third person or entity requiring production of personal and business records of the President and other persons and entities? The Court's answer to that question is yes."
This case is one of several others relating to Trump's efforts to keep his tax documents private. In this case, Vance subpoenaed Trump's accountants in an effort to collect eight years worth of tax returns for his investigation into claims of affairs and related payments. Judge Marrero stated that he could not provide such a "categorical and limitless assertion of presidential immunity" on several different grounds, including those ensuring a separation of powers between the federal branches of the government. The court also discussed the intention of the Constitutional Founders in viewing the president as both the figure leading the country and as a private citizen, thereby barring him from receiving absolute immunity. Based on historical and legal precedent, the court stated that Trump's motion, "unqualified and boundless in its reach as described above, cuts across the grain of these constitutional precedents".

item.title: TEST: Federal Judge dismisses tax lawsuit of Donald Trump
item.dc:creator: cmaas
item.content:encoded:
On Monday, the United States District Court of the Southern District of New York dismissed the tax lawsuit filed by Donald Trump. Trump filed suit seeking to enjoin enforcement of a subpoena issued by District Attorney of the county of New York Cyrus R. Vance, Jr. Trump contended that the person who assumes the role of President is subject to absolute immunity to criminal proceedings through the duration of presidency. This presidential immunity would cover every aspect of criminal procedure. The President would be immune until he left office by term expiration, resignation, or removal through impeachment and conviction. This would  potentially immunize any other person who may have collaborated with the president in committing unlawful acts that would normally result in criminal investigation. While recognizing that subjecting the President to criminal proceedings could interfere with or incapacitate the President's ability to conduct constitutional functions, the Court would not endorse the view of the "limitless assertion of presidential immunity." As United States District Judge Victor Marrero wrote:
Bared to its core, the proposition the President advances reduces to the very notion that the Founders rejected at the inception of the Republic, and that the Supreme Court has since unequivocally repudiated: that a constitutional domain exists in this country in which not only the President, but, derivatively relatives and persons and business entities associated with him in potentially unlawful private activities, are in fact above the law. Because this finds aspects of such a doctrine repugnant to the nation's governmental structure and constitutional values, and for the reasons further stated below it ABSTAINS from adjudicating this dispute and DISMISSES the President's suit.

item.title: Federal Judge Dismisses President's Lawsuit and Orders Trump to Comply with Subpoena for Tax Returns---DRAFT
item.dc:creator: abloomberg
item.content:encoded:
On Monday, the Federal District Court in Manhattan rejected President Donald Trump's claim of presidential immunity to judicial process, dismissing the lawsuit filed by the President.  A little more than a month ago the Manhattan District Attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., subpoenaed Mazars, USA, President Trump's accounting firm, requesting eight years of personal and corporate tax returns. Trump's lawyers filed to block the subpoena, arguing that the Constitution makes sitting presidents immune from all criminal investigations while in office. While the Judge Victor Marrero's  holding is limited to:
the President's compliance with a grand jury subpoena issued in the course of a state prosecutor's criminal investigation of conduct and transactions relating to third persons that occurred at least in part prior to the President assuming office, that may or may not have involved the President, but that at this phase of the proceedings demand review of records the President possesses or controls.
The Judge found that Donald Trump's expansive interpretation of Presidential immunity would constitute an overreach of executive power. At its core, Trump's theory of immunity would make the President and his relatives and business associates above the law. This is not the first time Donald Trump has sought an injunction to avoid the release of his tax returns. Last month, the President was granted a temporary injunction against California's Presidential Tax Transparency Accountability Act, which requires the release of a minimum of five years of tax returns to appear on the state's primary ballot.

item.title: TEST - Federal Judge rejects Trump's "extraordinary claims", orders to turn over tax returns
item.dc:creator: bbrown
item.content:encoded:
NEW YORK, New York - A federal judge has rejected President Trump's efforts to block a subpoena from the Manhattan DA requesting Mr. Trump's personal and business tax returns from 2011 to present. Judge Victor Marrerro of Manhattan federal court ruled Monday morning that the lawsuit brought by Trump to block that subpoena which included an "extraordinary claim" that, as President, he [Mr. Trump] "enjoys absolute immunity from criminal process of any kind," is "repugnant to the nation's government structures and constitutional values."
"In numerous rulings the courts have circumscribed claims of presidential immunity in multiple ways. Specifically , they have held that such protection from judicial process does not extend to civil suits regarding private conduct that occurred before the President assumed office, to responding to subpoenas regarding the conduct of third-persons , and to providing testimony in court proceedings relating to private disputes involving third persons."
The original subpoena stemmed from an investigation by the District Attorney into conduct in New York state. The grand jury subpoena served to the Trump Organization, LLC on August 1, 2019, was a part of that investigation, and sought documents and record from the Trump Organization for the period of time from June 2015 through September 2018. Later that same month on August 20, the subpoena at question was served to accounting firm Mazars USA, LLP ("Mazars") for the president's tax returns (and possibly others) from 2011 to present. The President and his counsel responded on September 19 by filing the complaint thrown out today by Judge Marrerro, which sought to halt the Mazars subpoena. In submitting their request for injunction and emergency restraining order on the Mazars injunction, the argument made by the President's complaint was, in brief, that as President of the United States, while in office, he enjoys immunity from investigations, criminal proceedings, indictment, prosecution, arrest, etc.

item.title: TEST --- New York federal judge dismisses Trump's complaint, refuses his claim of "absolute immunity from criminal process of any kind" --- PENDING
item.dc:creator: msullivan
item.content:encoded:
Judge Marrero of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York dismissed a lawsuit brought by President Trump on October 7th. The District Attorney of the county of New York issued a subpoena for President Trump's tax returns, and the president's lawsuit was filed with the argument that the President of the United States "while in office, enjoys absolute immunity from criminal process of any kind," under his view of the President's duties and powers in the United States Constitution. Judge Marrero dismissed the lawsuit, citing concerns about the precedent this would set, stating, "Consider the reach of the president's argument." He goes on to list a variety of events that this argument would affect, including all aspects of the judicial process (from simple investigation to incarceration), any of the President's affairs (whether they be related to his presidential duties or private affairs), and the possibility of an event where private citizens receive immunity simply because the President was involved in some way in a crime they committed. Judge Marrero's opinion continues for seventy-five pages, but can be summed up in a few of his statements:
"In practice, the implications and actual effects of the President's categorical rule could be far-reaching...This Court cannot endorse such a categorical and limitless assertion of presidential immunity from judicial process as being countenanced by the nation's constitutional plan, especially in the light of the fundamental concerns over excessive arrogation of power that animated the Constitution's delicate structure and its calibrated balance of authority among the three branches of the national government, as well as between the federal and state authorities. Hence, the expansive notion of constitutional immunity invoked here to shield the President from judicial process would constitute an overreach of executive power."
There will still be a lengthy appeal process to follow.

item.title: Federal judge rejects Trump's attempt to shield tax returns, appeals court immediately blocks order---HOLD
item.dc:creator: xshi
item.content:encoded: A federal judge on Monday dismissed US President Donald Trump's lawsuit seeking to enjoin the “Mazars Subpoena,” rejecting his claim that a president enjoys absolute immunity from criminal process of any kind. According to the President's argument, the constitutional dimensions of the presidential shield from judicial process would be virtually limitless, extending not only to his public misconduct, but also his private conduct as an ordinary citizen, and derivatively extend to anyone who may have collaborated with the President in committing purportedly unlawful acts. However, courts have repeatedly held that such protection from judicial process does not extend to civil suits regarding private conduct that occurred before the President assumed office, to responding to subpoenas regarding the conduct of third persons, and to providing testimony in court proceedings relating to private disputes involving third persons. The court held that the expansive notion of constitutional immunity invoked to shield the President from judicial process would constitute an overreach of executive power. "Such sweeping doctrine finds no support in the Constitution's text or history, or in germane guidance charted by rulings of the United States Supreme Court."

item.title: Scottish court refuses to force Boris Johnson to seek Brexit delay---HOLD
item.dc:creator: xshi
item.content:encoded: The Scottish court on Monday rejected a petition for coercive order to force the Prime Minister to ask for a Brexit delay. Relying on the Prime Minister's prior statements, the petitioners argued that the Prime Minister and the government intend unlawfully to refuse to carry out the statutory obligation imposed on the Prime Minister by section 1 of the European Union (Withdrawal) (No 2) Act 2019 ("the 2019 Act"). The underlying purpose of the 2019 Act is to ensure that the UK does not leave the EU on 31 October 2019 without a withdrawal agreement, unless the UK Parliament consents. The Act imposes on the Prime Minister a duty to negotiate the extension. However, the court noted that the government’s conduct of the negotiations with the EU with the aim of reaching a withdrawal agreement is not a matter that is justiciable in the courts. The court held it would neither be "necessary nor appropriate" to force the government to ask for a Brexit delay.

item.title: Republican Representative Chris Collins Found Guilty for Insider Trading---HOLD
item.dc:creator: kboyle
item.content:encoded: Republican Representative Chris Collins pled guilty to insider trading on October 1, 2019.  Collins, the former representative for New York's 27th District, was accused of using his status to obtain discounts on certain stocks for his son. He has been under the watch of the House's Office of Congressional Ethics since July 14th 2017, then the Office of Congressional Ethics recommended further review of Collin's actions by the House Committee on Ethics. In May of 2019, reopened the investigation with the help of the Department of Justice. On September 30th, 2019, Representative Collins resigned his seat due to the looming investigation. Representative Collin's specific charges include conspiracy to commit securities fraud and lying to the FBI. Collins is currently awaiting sentencing for his charges.

item.title: US blacklists 28 Chinese entities for abuse against Muslin minorities in Xinjiang---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ywang
item.content:encoded: The US Department of Commerce Bureau of Industry and Security announced Monday that 28 Chinese entities will be added to the Entity List, which identifies entities reasonably believed to be involved in activities contrary to the national security or foreign policy interests of the United States, for their alleged involvement in human rights violations and abuses in the implementation of China’s campaign of repression, mass arbitrary detention, and high-technology surveillance against Uighurs, Kazakhs, and other members of Muslim minority groups in Xinjiang Uighur Autonomous Region (XUAR). The End-User Review Committee (ERC) made the final rule pursuant to § 744.11 of the Export Administration Regulations (EAR), which imposes additional license requirements on exports, reexports, and transfers to listed entities. The 28 entities include XUAR People’s Government Public Security Bureau, eighteen of its subordinate municipal and county public security bureaus and one other subordinate institute, and eight other entities. The final rule is scheduled to be published in the Federal Register on Wednesday.

item.title: TEST- Washington electors petition the U.S. Supreme Court about fines for failing to vote for their party's nominees
item.dc:creator: jlusamba
item.content:encoded: On December 29,2016, the Washington Secretary of State fined Peter Bret Chiafalo, Levi Jennet Guerra and Esther Virginia John $1,000 each for voting for Colin Powell in the 2016 Presidential election instead of Hilary Clinton. Chiafalo, Guerra and John were appointed as electors for the Washington Democratic Party in the summer of 2016 and as such were expected to vote for the party's nominees for the 2016 Presidential election, namely Hilary Clinton for President and Tim Kaine for Vice-president. However, they voted Colin Powell for President and  Marie Cantwell (Guerra), Susan Collins (John) and  Elizabeth Warren (Chiafalo) for Vice-president, which was a direct violation of RCW 29A.56.340 (2016), a Washington statute which provides that "any elector who votes for a person or persons not nominated by the party of which he or she is an elector is subject to a civil penalty of up to $1,000." Chiafalo, Guerra and John appealed the fine to an administrative judge who upheld the fine, then to the Superior Court which rejected the appeal, and finally to the Washington Supreme Court which also upheld the fine.  They have, now, petitioned the U.S. Supreme Court for a writ of certiorari to determine whether the Constitution allows States to control how electors vote and whether such control through fines is a violation of the electors' First Amendment rights. Petitioners invoked Baca v. Colorado Department of State as a reason why the U.S. Supreme Court should grant their petition. Baca v. Colorado Department of State is a similar case where the 10th Circuit held, merely two months after the Washington Supreme Court decision on petitioners' case, that such control by the State was unconstitutional.  Petitioners contend that such a split in views of the States' power to control how electors vote required a final determination by the U.S. Supreme Court. Petitioners also pointed out as a reason why their petition should be granted, that this was the perfect opportunity for the U.S. Supreme Court to settle this important issue outside of the heated atmosphere of a contested presidential election.

item.title: TEST-- Petitioned filed with Supreme Court asks, Can presidential electors vote their conscience?-- DRAFT
item.dc:creator: abloomberg
item.content:encoded: Three presidential electors in Washington State were fined under state law for not casting their vote in line with the popular vote in 2016; they have petitioned the Supreme Court to hear their case. The question before the court is: is enforcement of RCW 29A.56.340 (2016) unconstitutional because (1) the law has no power to legally enforce how a presidential voter casts his/her ballot?; (2) a state penalizing a presidential voter for using their constitutional discretion is a violation of the first amendment. There is a split between the state and federal courts on this important constitutional issue. The Washington Supreme Court found the constitution did allow for imposing fines on presidential electors that acted "faithlessly" by not casting their vote in line with the popular vote. In a contradictory opinion, the 10th Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals held that Colorado violated the Constitution when it removed a presidential elector who acted faithlessly. The filing is spearheaded by Lawrence Lessig, of Harvard Law School, on behalf of his group Equal Citizens. Lessig has publicly urged presidential electors to vote their conscience and advocates for states to join the National Popular Vote compact, which would pledge electors to the national popular vote automatically. The petition urges the Supreme Court to resolve the issue of presidential electors voting their conscience before the 2020 election so that state's have time to respond before the Presidential election. This petition presents a rare opportunity for the Court to "resolve an important electoral issue...without any external time pressure or obvious political implications".

item.title: Federal Judge Rejects Trump's Claim for Criminal Immunity
item.dc:creator: cstephens
item.content:encoded: On Monday, a federal judge rejected President Trump’s lawsuit asserting executive immunity from criminal processes. The decision comes after Manhattan District Attorney, Cyrus Vance, subpoenaed eight years of Trump’s tax returns. Though Trump has not faced any charges in relation to the probe, his legal team argued that such an immunity is necessary for functioning of the office. By sustaining exposure to criminal proceedings, the President will not be able to fulfill his duties. In a lengthy opinion, United States District Judge Victor Marrero states executive immunity over all criminal proceedings offends the United States’ historical and Constitutional system of governance. He writes, “the expansive notional of constitutional immunity invoked here to shield the President from judicial process would constitute an overreach of executive power.” The court also takes aim at the frequently cited DOJ Memos that urge federal prosecutors to refrain from indicting a sitting President. Specifically, the court finds that such memos have minimal weight, provided that they are not binding law. Marrero concludes the theory of the memos “have assumed substantial legal force as if their conclusion were inscribed on constitutional tablets so-etched by the Supreme Court.” Though this is a victory for the Manhattan District Attorney Office, Vance will need to wait to obtain Trump’s tax returns. The New York Times reports the President’s legal team succeeded in temporarily blocking the order.

item.title: Federal Court Dismisses President's Criminal Immunity Claim
item.dc:creator: jdougherty
item.content:encoded: The United States District Court, Southern District of New York dismisses President Trumps lawsuit to block subpoenas filled by the United States of New York Cyrus Vance. The subpoenas, known as the "Mazars Subpoenas," were issued to Mazars, LLP, for various documents, and records, including the tax returns since January 2011. The subpoenas issued were related to a criminal investigation of a third party, at least in part, prior to, the President taking office. In his action to block the subpoenas, the President claimed that the president enjoys absolute immunity from criminal processes of any kind. Its opinion written by Judge Victor Merrero, the court dismisses the President's "extraordinary claim" that is "virtually limitless." The court stated, "the expansive notion of constitutional immunity invoked here to shield the President from judicial immunity would constitute an overreach of executive power." The court found several reasons for dismissing the President's claim. The first was based on the Anti-Injunction Act that states that a "court of the United States may not grant an injunction to stay proceedings in a State except as expressly authorized by Act of Congress . . ." The court found that the New York state courts were capable of handling the case at issue, and it is not the federal court's place to interrupt. Additionally, the court looked to the Supreme Court's guidance to take into account several considerations regarding presidential immunity from the judicial process related to a criminal proceeding. After review, the court found that the President does not have immunity from criminal proceedings. The court dismissed the claims and order the subpoenas be answered by 1:00 PM on Monday, October 7, 2019.

item.title: TEST --- DC Circuit Court of Appeals affirms lower court summary judgement, Trump must comply with congressional tax return subpeona --- PENDING
item.dc:creator: msullivan
item.content:encoded: Just four days after the US District Court for the Southern District of New York ruled that President Trump must comply with the District Attorney's grand jury subpoena, the DC Circuit Court of Appeals has done the same. In April 2019, the House Committee on Oversight and Reform issued a subpoena for eight years of President Trump's tax returns. Congress is looking at whether they should amend or supplement current ethics-in-government laws. It claims the President's tax returns will be of great benefit in the investigation. President Trump filed a lawsuit, stating the the Congressional inquiry has "no legitimate legislative purpose", and that Mazars (the accounting firm with his financial records) does not need to comply with the subpoena. The district court granted summary judgment against President Trump. The DC Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment. In their opinion, the Circuit Court details the history that led to this specific subpoena. They start with the omission of President Trump's reimbursement to Michael Cohen for his payments to cover up the President's extramarital affairs. The Court then dives into the history of legislative subpoenas in the United States, going back to 1792. The Court ultimately states that Congress cannot overreach and that their subpoenas may only apply to "information 'calculated to' 'materially aid' their investigations. Even a valid legislative purpose cannot justify a subpoena demanding irrelevant material." At the end of the sixty-six page opinion, the Court concludes that this general scenario is nothing new. "Disputes between Congress and the President are a recurring plot in our national story. And that is precisely what the Framers intended." Mazars is ordered to comply with the subpoena.

item.title: TEST- Gov. Gavin Newsom Vetoes Bill Regarding Signature Gatherers
item.dc:creator: cmaas
item.content:encoded: On Monday, October 7, Governor Gavin Newsom of California vetoed an assembly bill that made paying signature gatherers based on the number of signatures that they gather a misdemeanor. Based upon this bill, anyone who pays money or any other thing of value to a person based on the number of signatures obtained on a state or local initiative, referendum, or recall petition would be guilty of a misdemeanor. This would be punishable by a specified fine, imprisonment, or both. This bill was introduced on January 29, 2019 as an act to add to the Elections Code. Governor Newsom vetoed this bill because the bill would create barriers to citizen participation in the electoral process. The qualification of many initiatives would become cost-prohibitive. As Governor Newsom wrote, "I am a strong supporter of of California's system of direct democracy and am reluctant to sign any bill that erects barriers to citizen participation in the electoral process."

item.title: Test----California governor vetoes paid for signatures crime bill ---review
item.dc:creator: rsalamacha

item.title: Test --- practice article #3
item.dc:creator: zgujral
item.content:encoded: The 6th Circuit Court struck down Ohio's law banning abortions due to a prenatal diagnosis of Down Syndrome, upholding an injunction by a lower court. Ohio law H.B. 214 was signed into law on Dec 22, 2017 and amended Section 3701.79 of the Ohio Revised Code and enacted Sections 2919.10 and 2919.101. 2919.10 prohibited "any person from purposefully performing or inducing or attempting to perform or induce an abortion if the person has knowledge that the pregnant woman is  seeking the abortion, in whole or in part," because the fetus has tested positive for Down Syndrome, or there is reason to believe that the fetus has Down Syndrome. The law made such an abortion a fourth-degree felony, punishable by up to 18 months in prison. The State argued that the law was designed to prevent discrimination against people with Down Syndrome. Since prenatal testing for Down Syndrome has become easily accessible, over 70% of women whose fetus is diagnosed with Down Syndrome choose to terminate their pregnancies. Though, depending on the region the rates vary from 61% to 93%. Due to associated medical problems, children born with Down Syndrome generally didn't survive past infancy or into early adulthood. With modern medical care children can live to 50 to 60 years old, with a small percentage surviving into their 70s. People with Down Syndrome require fairly constant care, or at least monitoring and rarely graduate high school or hold down a paid job. The 6th Curcuit disagreed with the Defendants arguments that Roe v Wade and Planned Parenthood v Casey did not apply because in both cases the Supreme Court has recognized a right to personal privacy, which is rooted in several of the Amendments to the Constitution. The Defendants argued that while under Roe a woman has the right to terminate her pregnancy prior to viability, that right is not absolute. The 6th Circuit disagreed. While the State does have an interest in preserving life, those interests are not sufficient to prohibit abortions prior to viability. The Defendants also argued that the law is attempting to prevent discrimination against people with disabilities. The Court disagreed because the State's interests in preventing discrimination are intertwined with the State's interests in protecting potential life. "Without the potential life, there would be not interest in preventing discrimination." Based on the above reasons, and evidence that women seeking an abortion would be irreparably harmed because they would be denied their constitutional right to an abortion, the 6th Circuit upheld the lower court's injunction. "... a State may not prohibit any woman from making the ultimate decision to terminate her pregnancy before viability."

item.title: TEST — Ohio federal court rules abortion ban after Down syndrome diagnosis unconstitutional
item.dc:creator: msullivan
item.content:encoded: Sixth Circuit US Court of Appeals ruled on Friday that an Ohio law banning abortion of fetuses (regardless of viability) diagnosed with Down syndrome to be unconstitutional. The Ohio law prohibits physicians from performing abortions that are sought because of, or at least in part because of a fetal Down syndrome diagnosis. The law requires physicians to sign a statement saying they are not aware of any reasons relating to Down syndrome in the pregnant woman’s choice to abort her unviable fetus. Violation of the law constitutes a fourth-degree felony, punishable by up to eighteen months in prison, as well as the revocation of the physician’s medical license by the state medical board. The lower court struck down the complaint, stating that Roe and Casey were controlling law, and the plaintiffs were likely to succeed. This is a legal judicial justification for granting a preliminary injunction. The defendants argued that the Supreme Court used language in Roe that specifically stated that pre-viability abortion is not an “absolute” right. They argued that because of this, the lower court was erroneous is granting the preliminary injunction. The Court of Appeals affirmed the lower court’s decision. The Court cites the Constitutional right to privacy. They make the assertion that the lower court didn’t determine whether a woman’s right to a pre-viability abortion is absolute. Rather, the lower court determined that women have the Constitutional right to privacy when it comes to their reason for obtaining an abortion. The Court of Appeals also determined that the lower court correctly exercised the judicial ability to grant a preliminary injunction.

item.title: Test - DC Circuit Court affirms denial of Trump tax release appeal
item.dc:creator: jlamp
item.content:encoded: The D.C. Circuit Court upheld a lower court decision on Friday, requiring Mazars to release information, including tax records, concerning President Donald Trump and his affiliated businesses. The court's ruling can in response to the president's attempt to block a subpoena issued in April by the House Committee on Oversight and Reform. Trump's lawyers argued the subpoena was invalid, stating it did not adhere to the requirement that legislative inquiries target an objective of effecting legislation. The court, however, found the argument unpersuasive, stating: "In sum, we detect no inherent constitutional flaw in laws requiring Presidents to publicly disclose certain financial information. And that is enough...[W]e conclude that given the constitutionally permissible options open to Congress in the field of financial disclosure, the challenged subpoena seeks 'information about a subject on which legislation may be had.'" The court's ruling deals another blow to the president's attempts to block investigations into his business dealings before and after taking office. Last week, a federal court ruled the president could not stop another subpoena seeking records similar to those sought by the House committee.

item.title: TEST - Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals upholds injunction on Ohio Down Syndrome abortion ban
item.dc:creator: ebeeken
item.content:encoded:
This past Friday, the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals upheld an injunction preventing Ohio from enforcing a 2017 bill banning abortion when medical tests show that the fetus has Down Syndrome. The Court was divided, ruling 2-1 to uphold the injunction. A violation of the statute would result in a felony, punishable by up to 18 months in prison.
"Section 2919.10 prohibits any person from purposefully performing or inducing or attempting to perform or induce an abortion if the person has knowledge that the pregnant woman is seeking the abortion, in whole or in part, because of any of the following: (1) a test result indicating Down Syndrome in an unborn child; (2) a prenatal diagnosis of Down Syndrome in an unborn child; or (3) “any other reason to believe” that an unborn child has Down Syndrome."
The Court considered four factors when reviewing the injunction: whether the plaintiffs would prevail on the merits of their injunction, whether the moving party would be harmed without the injunction, whether others would be substantially harmed without the injunction, and whether the public has an interest in granting the injunction. The majority decided that whether the moving party would prevail on the merits was the determinative factor. Ohio's attorneys claimed that "the panel should reverse the district court’s decision because the district court applied an erroneous legal standard by creating an absolute or categorical right to a pre-viability abortion." The Court rejected this claim on the grounds that Roe v. Wade and Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pa. v. Casey established that the State does not have an interest until viability of the fetus. Circuit Judge Batchelder dissented, asserting that this injunction is similar to modern-day eugenics.

item.title: TEST --- Federal appeals court upholds injunction against Ohio down-syndrome abortion ban
item.dc:creator: gwast
item.content:encoded:
The US Sixth District Court of Appeals affirmed on Friday the granting of a preliminary injunction preventing the state of Ohio from enforcing House bill 214. H.B. 214 bars abortion providers from performing abortions when the patient is seeking treatment because the fetus has Down Syndrome. State officials from Ohio appealed after the Southern District of Ohio District Court granted the preliminary injunction for the plaintiffs. Circuit Judge Donald, joined by Judge Cole, mirrored the reasoning of the district court and reviewed the guidelines of granting a preliminary injunction:
To determine whether to grant a preliminary injunction, trial courts consider and balance four factors: (1) the likelihood that the moving party will prevail on the merits; (2) whether the moving party will be irreparably harmed absent the injunction; (3) the prospect that others will be substantially harmed if the court grants the injunction; and (4) the public interest in granting the injunction.
The appeals court held that the district court's granting of a preliminary injunction was appropriate because it met each of these standards. First, the Plaintiffs have a strong case based on federal precedent. The court agrees that both the Plaintiffs and others would be harmed if it is found that this bill is unconstitutional, yet enforced. Lastly, the public would be against enforcing a potentially unconstitutional bill. Because the appeals court found no error in law or fact and a proper analysis by the district court, the decision was affirmed. Judge Batchelder wrote a dissent stating that the bill is not unconstitutional as it prevents eugenics through abortions. The judge noted that it is important to note the benefits of the law, not just the burden it places on those seeking abortions. She goes on to say that "[n]either the district court nor the majority here makes a genuine attempt to [acknowlegde the benefits], which leaves their decisions insupportable and incorrect."

item.title: TEST - Congressional subpoena for Trump's tax returns is upheld in U.S. Court of Appeals
item.dc:creator: amauroni
item.content:encoded:
The efforts to secure President Donald Trump's tax returns with a Congressional subpoena continue with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia denying Trump's appeal on Friday:
In sum, we detect no inherent constitutional flaw in laws requiring Presidents to publicly disclose certain financial information. And that is enough. Without treading onto any other potentially fertile grounds from which constitutional legislation could flower, we conclude that given the constitutionally permissible options open to Congress in the field of financial disclosure, the challenged subpoena seeks 'information about a subject on which legislation may be had.' Eastland, 421 U.S. at 508.
This subpoena, which originated from the Committee on Oversight and Reform, is one of several attempts currently occurring throughout the country to obtain Trump's tax returns. The subpoena was issued to the accounting firm Mazars USA, LLP, and include records that are related both to Trump's work and that conducted by his business offices. The records originate from both before and after Trump's time in office began. This subpoena is based on the Ethics in Government Acts of 1978 that was originally passed "requir[ing] many aspiring and current government officials, including presidential candidates and sitting Presidents, to file financial disclosure reports at various times during their candidacies and incumbencies." Last year, the Office of Government Ethics identified an error in one of Trump's documents, that being a failure to report a payment made by Mr. Michael Cohen to a third party while Cohen was Trump's personal lawyer. The office determined this to be considered a reportable liability under the Act. The committee requested documentation from Trump but received no answer. This led them to request to documentation from Mazars, which responded that it could not voluntarily provide it. The committee thus filed a subpoena to Mazars. Trump filed a lawsuit in response to the subpoena, requesting that the district court invalidate it and prohibit its action. However, the court granted summary judgment to the committee, and Trump appealed the judgement to the U.S. Federal District Court of Appeals. Citing more than a hundred years of case law precedent granting the legislature investigative powers, even in regard to the president, the U.S. Court of Appeals denied Trump's appeal. The court reviewed whether the subpoena was issued on legislative or law enforcement grounds, and in determining the subpoena to have been issued on a legislative basis, the court upheld the previous ruling.

item.title: Federal appeals court upholds injunction on Ohio Down's Syndrome abortion ban law
item.dc:creator: abloomberg
item.content:encoded: A two to one ruling from the Sixth Circuit on Friday upheld a preliminary injunction against enforcement of a 2017 abortion ban in Ohio. The law prohibits abortion providers from performing abortions when the decision is based on a diagnosis or indicator of Down Syndrome. The ACLU filed the lawsuit on behalf of the state's abortion providers arguing for an injunction because it violates a woman's right to privacy under Roe. The state of Ohio argued that the ban is not unconstitutional because it furthers the state's interest in preventing discrimination based on disability, which must be balanced with a woman's right to privacy. The Sixth Circuit majority agreed with the district court's finding that "under Roe and Casey, a woman is expressly and unambiguously entitled to a pre-viability right to choose whether to terminate or continue her pregnancy". Allowing state interest in preventing discrimination to extend to "potential life" would ignore the unique condition of abortion recognized in Casey. Therefore, "the state's interest in preventing discrimination does not become compelling until viability". In her dissent, Judge Batchelder argued that the state did have an interest in counteracting "eugenicist practices concerning the prenatal Down Syndrome population". In her opinion, the majority applied the wrong standard, and should have applied the "undue burden" standard, which would have led to a finding of constitutionality. Friday's ruling means that for now the Ohio abortion ban will not be allowed to take effect until the outcome of the ACLU's lawsuit.

item.title: Test ---Federal circuit court denied president's appeal of congressional tax return subpoena ---Draft
item.dc:creator: rsalamacha
item.content:encoded:
The D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals on Friday denied President Trump's appeal over a congressional subpoena requesting his tax returns.  The House Committee on Oversight and Reform sent the subpoena to president's accounting firm this past March.  The committee filed the subpoena to aid in its investigation over Michael Cohen's committee testimony last February.  In his testimony, Cohen, the president's former lawyer, alleged that the president had inflated his assets in statements to Deutsche Bank and insurance companies.  Cohen supplied the committee with financial statements prepared by the president's accountants from 2011, 2012, and 2013.  The committee noted concerns over financial claims in the statements and created an investigation. The president's appeal followed the D.C. District Court ruling that found the subpoena to be within the scope of congressional legislative powers.  During initial arguments, the president asserted that the subpoena had no legislative purpose and should be blocked.  He claimed that the subpoena was a political maneuver and only collected personal information.  However, the court held that congressional investigative authority extends to any subject which "legislation could be had."  The president's financial activities fell under that standard according to the court, and the court granted summary judgment in favor of the committee to enforce the subpoena. Upon appeal to the circuit court, the circuit court clearly distinguished that the committee did not subpoena the president himself.  Instead, the committee subpoenaed the president's accounting firm. Because of this distinction, the circuit court asserted that the case did not present an issue over conflicting separation of powers. Additionally, the circuit court found that congress had delegated proper authority to the committee to issue the subpoena and conduct the investigation. The circuit court stated that the investigation was appropriate, echoing the district court's holding that the investigation was over a subject that could be legislated. The circuit court furthered that the subpoena "materially aid[s]" the committee investigation. The subpoenaed materials include returns for years during the president's candidacy. According to the circuit court, these returns are relevant to remedial legislation outlined in committee chairman memos. The circuit court affirmed the district court's ruling. The House Committee on Oversight and Reform published a press release over the circuit court ruling late Friday.  The committee chairman, Elijah Cummings, praised the appeals court's decision:
“Today’s ruling is a fundamental and resounding victory for Congressional oversight, our Constitutional system of checks and balances, and the rule of law. For far too long, the President has placed his personal interests over the interests of the American people. After months of delay, it is time for the President to stop blocking Mazars from complying with the Committee’s lawful subpoena. We must fulfill our stated legislative and oversight objectives and permit the American people to obtain answers about some of the deeply troubling questions regarding the President’s adherence to Constitutional and statutory requirements to avoid conflicts of interest.”
The committee is now free to execute its subpoena of the president's tax returns based on these judicial rulings.

item.title: TEST- Federal appeals court says Ohio cannot enforce abortion ban when unborn has Down syndrome
item.dc:creator: cmaas
item.content:encoded:
The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit said on Friday that Ohio law House Bill 214 cannot be enforced. Various abortion providers sued the state officials responsible for implementing and enforcing Ohio law House Bill 214, which prohibits abortion if there is knowledge or an indication that the unborn has Down syndrome. The abortion providers alleged that the bill was unconstitutional, as it inhibited pre-viability abortions based upon a woman's reasons for seeking that abortion and therefore violated patients’ rights to liberty and privacy, as guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment. The Court of Appeals reviewed and affirmed the district court's grant of preliminary injunction to prevent the enforcement and implementation of House Bill 214, as there was a likelihood that the statute was unconstitutional. As written in the court opinion:
As to the likelihood that the moving party would be irreparably harmed, Plaintiffs’ patients would be irreparably harmed as a matter of law by the loss of their constitutional right to seek an abortion before viability... A preliminary injunction in this case would merely preserve the status quo and ensure Plaintiffs’ patients have access to constitutionally protected health care services through the duration of the case.
