The Court of Appeals said that Bill 214 could infringe upon a patient's constitutional rights. By upholding the injunction, patients could continue to have access to protected health care services.

item.title: TEST - DC Circuit Court denies Trump appeal to congressional subpoena for financial records
item.dc:creator: bbrown
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. Court of Appeals for the DC circuit overruled President Trump's appeal of a lower court's decision to allow the congressional subpoena for financial records backdating eight years from his accounting firm. In the 66-page opinion from the court's 2-1 ruling, Judges David S. Tatel and Patricia A. Millet (both Democratic president appointees) wrote that the subpoena for the financial records from accounting firm Mazars fell in line with a history of cases upholding the Congressional authority to investigate - denying Trump's argument that the subpoenas "served no legitimate legislative purpose."
A congressional committee, as committees have done repeatedly over the past two centuries, issued an investigative subpoena, and the target of that subpoena, questioning the committee’s legislative purpose, has asked a court to invalidate it. The fact that the subpoena in this case seeks information that concerns the President of the United States adds a twist, but not a surprising one: disputes between Congress and the President are a recurring plot in our national story. And that is precisely what the Framers intended. As Justice Brandeis wrote, “[t]he doctrine of the separation of powers was adopted . . . not to promote efficiency but to preclude the exercise of arbitrary power.” Myers v. United States, 272 U.S. 52, 293 (1926) (Brandeis, J., dissenting). “The purpose,” he explained, “was not to avoid friction, but, by means of the inevitable friction incident to the distribution of the governmental powers among three departments, to save the people from autocracy.”
The original congressional subpoena, which this court calls a  "valid exercise of legislative oversight authority," is just one of several legal battles between the President and the House over personal and business records, both from Trump's time before and during his presidency. The request by the  House Oversight Committee's  for audits and financial statements prepared for Trump and his companies by accounting firm Mazars USA began months before the more current impeachment inquiries by the House over Trump's alleged request that Ukraine investigate Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden. While the more recent impeachment inquiries still rule headlines, the former financial record requests from the House to Mazars USA was prompted by the testimony that dominated news cycles when former Trump attorney Michael Cohen's testimony suggested that the president exaggerated his wealth when seeking loans. While the DC Circuit Court's recent overturning of Trump's appeal to block the Mazars subpoenas and their 66 page explanation of why it is the House's unprecedented "right" to investigate as such, the question of whether Trump's team will seek a higher appeal still remains looming. Trumps' cousel has said they'll think about it:  "we continue to believe that this subpoena is not a legitimate exercise of Congress’s legislative authority,” said Jay Sekulow, one of Trump’s private attorneys, in a statement. William Consovoy, the president’s lawyer in the case, declined to comment on the ruling or the legal team’s next steps. The House has said they will not enforce the subpoenas while Trump's appeal is still in process. Whether a further appeal will occur is still to be decided, but for not, what is decided is this latest ruling in the ongoing battle for Trump's documents.

item.title: TEST- Court affirm's injunction of Ohio law that ban's abortion of fetuses with Down syndrome
item.dc:creator: vnegron
item.content:encoded: The sixth circuit court of appeals ruled on Friday to affirm the injunction against House bill 214 which bans abortion if a woman suspects or knows a fetus has Down syndrome. The court held the injunction was justified because: "Defendants attempt to place H.B. 214 outside the scope of Roe and Casey by asserting an interest in preventing discrimination and arguing that Roe and Casey apply only to the state’s interest in the woman’s health and potential life. This argument lacks rigor and is deceptive in its construction. The Supreme Court has made clear that, before viability, the state’s purported reason for prohibiting a woman from obtaining an abortion is not dispositive." The defendants are relying on an argument that they seek to prevent discrimination so HB.214 should be outside of the scope of Roe and Casey. The court here says the argument fails because it was clearly established in Casey that before a fetus is viable women have the right to an abortion without state interference and that is what is happening here. The decision was split 2-1 with Judge Batchelder dissenting. Judge Batchelder agrees with the defendant's argument that this in an anti-discrimination bill and thus falls outside of the scope of Roe and Casey.  While the decision is split the injunction will continue to be upheld and the future of the law is in question.

item.title: Test - Federal appeals court upholds injunction against Ohio ban on abortion based on down syndrome - Pending
item.dc:creator: jcossin
item.content:encoded:
The US Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit, on Friday, upheld an injunction against a controversial law in Ohio banning abortion based on down syndrome. The court found, in a 2-1 decision, that the ACLU's lawsuit contained sufficient grounds to warrant a continued injunction until the case is resolved. The law, H.B. 214, would prohibit abortion providers from performing abortions "with the knowledge that the decision to abort" at least in part "arises from a diagnosis or indication that the unborn child has Down Syndrome." The plaintiffs are several abortion providers from Ohio. They allege that "H.B. 214 unconstitutionally inhibits pre-viability abortions based on a woman’s reason for seeking the abortion." The lower court granted the preliminary injunction on the grounds that "the plaintiffs had shown a likelihood of success on the merits." The lower court also found "that under Roe and Casey, a woman is expressly and unambiguously entitled to a pre-viability right to choose whether to terminate or continue her pregnancy." In their appeal, the defendants alleged that "the district court applied an erroneous legal standard by creating an 'absolute' or 'categorical' right to a pre-viability abortion." They asked the court to find that "their alleged state interest in preventing discrimination based on a disability does not fall under Roe and Casey" because neither Supreme Court decision considered such an interest. They also allege that considering the state's interest in preventing discrimination based on disability, the plaintiffs have not shown a likelihood of success on the merits. The US Court of Appeals relied heavily on the Casey opinion in their ruling, directly quoting from it with emphasis added to illustrate its applicability to this case.
"'[A] statute which, while furthering the interest in potential life' or some other valid state interest, 'has the effect of placing a substantial obstacle in the path of a woman’s choice cannot be considered a permissible means of serving its legitimate ends.'"
With Roe and Casey as guidelines, the court concluded that the state's interest in preventing discrimination does not manifest until a fetus has reached viability.
"Accordingly, we conclude that H.B. 214 is subject to the precedent set forth in Roe and Casey and, therefore, the state’s interest in preventing discrimination does not become compelling until viability."
The State is expected to appeal this decision to the whole court.  Any ruling by the court is also likely to be appealed to the Supreme Court, where many anti-abortion advocates hope to see a reversal of the Roe and Casey decisions by a more conservative Supreme Court.

item.title: TEST- District of Columbia Circuit Court of Appeals requires President Trump to comply with subpoena
item.dc:creator: enapoleon
item.content:encoded:
The District of Columbia Circuit Court of Appeals denied President Trump's appeal of a congressional subpoena for his tax returns on Friday. In April, the House Committee on Oversight and Reform issued an initial subpoena to Mazars USA, requiring records related to work performed for President Trump and his multiple businesses. The Committee argued that these documents would help inform how Congress should amend current ethics-in-government laws. The President, on the other hand, argued that this inquiry had no direct link to the legislature, thus the initial suit commenced in an attempt to prevent Mazars from complying with the subpoena. The Circuit Court of Appeals based their decision to affirm the imposition of the subpoena on the Ethics in Government Act of 1978. In response to the Watergate scandal, this Act was enacted to require aspiring and current government officials to disclose their finances during various times of their candidacies and incumbencies. Last year, the Office of Government Ethics discovered that President Trump omitted a payment made by Mr. Michael Cohen to a third party in the disclosure of his finances. As a result of this omission, further inquiries into Trump’s finances were made. Through the various suits President Trump has filed in his attempt to contest the subpoena, he has argued that the subpoenas overstep judicial powers and are in turn unconstitutional. Circuit Judge Tatel states however,
“Though our journey has been long, we find ourselves at the end of a familiar tale. A congressional committee, as committees have done repeatedly over the past two centuries, issued an investigative subpoena, and the target of that subpoena, questioning the committee’s legislative purpose, has asked a court to invalidate it. The fact that the subpoena in this case seeks information that concerns the President of the Unites States adds a twist, but not a surprising one: disputes between Congress and the President are a recurring plot in our national story. And that is precisely what the Framers intended.”
President Trump’s argument is deteriorated by precedent and the intent of the Framers of the Constitution. This is a case of checks and balances, even though the President believes otherwise.

item.title: TEST - Circuit court denies president's appeal of subpoena for his tax returns
item.dc:creator: tgillett
item.content:encoded: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia in a 2-to-1 vote issued a ruling last week denying President Trump's appeal of a congressional subpoena for his tax returns from 2011 through 2018. In April of this year the House Committee on Oversight and Reform issued a subpoena to the President's long-time accounting firm Mazars USA for financial documents related to the President and his business activities. Trump had filed a lawsuit to block the subpoena, which failed in district court, which led to this appeal to overturn the district court. In disputing the district court ruling, the president contended both that the Committee lacked the requisite authority from the House of Representatives to issue the subpoena, and disputed whether the House had the authority under the Constitution to confer the subpoena power to the Committee. The circuit court denied the president's claim that the committee's investigation "serve[d] no legitimate legislative purpose," finding instead that the committee was well within its authority under both House rules and the Constitution to issue the subpoena for the president's taxes. In affirming the lower court's ruling, the circuit court found ample precedent for Congress' investigative powers, noting that "legislative subpoenas are older than our country itself," and that the Supreme Court has long upheld Congress' power to conduct such investigations, even when the investigation involves the executive branch; "[D]isputes between Congress and the President," the majority concluded, "are a recurring plot in our national story. And that is precisely what the Framers intended."

item.title: TEST- DC Circuit Court denies Tump's tax records appeal
item.dc:creator: vnegron
item.content:encoded:
The DC Circuit Court, on Friday, denied President Trump's appeal to keep his financial records from the House committees that requested them. The house committees requested the information to amend their ethics guidelines but President Trump claims they have no legislative reason to ask for his financial records.
"Though our journey has been long, we find ourselves at the end of a familiar tale. A congressional committee, as committees have done repeatedly over the past two centuries, issued an investigative subpoena, and the target of that subpoena, questioning the committee’s legislative purpose, has asked a court to invalidate it... Having considered the weighty interests at stake in this case, we conclude that the subpoena issued by the Committee 66 to Mazars is valid and enforceable"
The court goes through a long process to come to the conclusion that there is nothing constitutionally wrong or otherwise illegal about the committee requesting the information. Further, Trump cannot expect this court to declare a statute that does not exist as illegal and they must wait until something is enacted to come to court. The court affirms the summary judgement and Mazars must turn over the requested records.

item.title: TEST- 6th Circuit Court of Appeals states that Ohio cannot enforce a 2017 abortion law
item.dc:creator: enapoleon
item.content:encoded: The 6th Circuit Court of Appeals decided on Friday that Ohio can not enforce a 2017 law banning abortions when medical tests show that a fetus has Down Syndrome. Plaintiff in this suit claim that this law violates their Fourteenth Amendment rights to liberty and privacy, and thus is unconstitutional. More specifically, a woman’s reasoning for seeking an abortion prevents her from actually receiving that pre-viability abortion. In arriving at their decision, the court relied heavily on Roe and Casey. In Roe v Wade, the court held a woman could obtain an abortion “for whatever reasons she aloe chooses.” In addition, the court stated, “With respect to the State’s important and legitimate interest in potential life the ‘compelling’ point is at viability This is so because the fetus then presumably has the capability of meaningful life outside the mother’s womb. State regulation protective of fetal life after viability thus has nth logical and biological justifications. If the State is interested in protecting fetal life after viability, it may go so far as to proscribe abortion during that period, except when it is necessary to preserve the life of health of the mother.” Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania v Casey upheld the ruling of Roe v Wade about twenty years after the initial decision. In this case the court stated that “before viability, the state’s interests are not strong enough to support a prohibition of abortion…Regardless of whether exceptions are made for particular circumstances, a State may not prohibit any woman from making the ultimate decision to terminate her pregnancy before viability.” The use of Roe and Casey shows the Ohio Legislature’s infringement on an individual’s constitutional rights.

item.title: TEST Federal appeals court rules against enforcement of abortion bans for fetuses with Down syndrome
item.dc:creator: vbesteman

item.title: TEST California governor signs bill to ban sale of animal fur products
item.dc:creator: vbesteman
item.content:encoded: California Governor Gavin Newsom signed Assembly Bill 44 on Saturday, allowing for a ban on the sale of animal fur products. The law will go into effect in January of 2023. The bill exempts used fur products, fur products used for specified purposes (e.g. religious purposes), and any activity expressly authorized by federal law. Those who sell or trade any of the fur products that are exempted from the bill are required to maintain records of sales or trades for at least one year. Violators of the bill will be subject to civil penalties at the authorization of the department, the Attorney General, or the city attorney, district attorney, or county counsel.

item.title: TEST --- California becomes first state to ban sale of new animal furs
item.dc:creator: gwast
item.content:encoded: The Governor of California approved Assembly Bill No. 44 on Monday, which bans the sale of animal furs in California. Both the selling and manufacturing of new fur products will be illegal in the state of starting January 1, 2023. The bill exempts the sale of used fur products, fur products for religious, tribal, or cultural purposes, or uses authorized by federal law. Violation of the statute may be tried as a misdemeanor, or with a civil penalty. After a person's first violation the penalty will be $500. As the violations accumulate the penalty increases based on the number of offenses up to $1000. Each fur product will be considered a separate violation and each will be treated with a penalty. Along with AB-44, Governor Gavin Newsom signed legislation banning some animals from being used in the circus, prohibiting the hunting of California bobcats, protecting horses from slaughter and more. In a statement, the Governor said “California is a leader when it comes to animal welfare and today that leadership includes banning the sale of fur."

item.title: Test---Circuit court halts Ohio law that bans abortion if fetus has Down Syndrome
item.dc:creator: rsalamacha
item.content:encoded:
The Sixth Circuit United States Court of Appeals affirmed a district court's ruling against an Ohio abortion law on Friday.  The law criminalized performing an abortion for partial or whole reason that the fetus was suspected of having Down Syndrome.  The Ohio Governor signed the bill, HB 214, that became law in December of 2017.  HB 214 required that a physician attest in writing that the abortion was not done because the mother suspected that the fetus had Down Syndrome.  It imposed fourth-degree felony and up to 18 months in prison for doctors who performed an abortion with knowledge that the mother sought abortion because the mother had a reason to believe the fetus had Down Syndrome. The decision follows the District Court for the Southern District of Ohio's grant of a preliminary injunction in March of 2018.  In the injunction, the district court ordered that Ohio could not implement or enforce HB 214, because the pro-choice plaintiffs presented authoritative cases that would likely result in a judgment in their favor.  The appeals court affirmed the district court's injunction and stated its criteria that determined the affirmation:
To determine whether to grant a preliminary injunction, trial courts consider and balance four factors: (1) the likelihood that the moving party will prevail on the merits; (2) whether the moving party will be irreparably harmed absent the injunction; (3) the prospect that others will be substantially harmed if the court grants the injunction; and (4) the public interest in granting the injunction.  City of Pontiac Retired Emps. Ass’n v. Schimmel, 751 F.3d 427, 430 (6th Cir. 2014) (en banc).  These factors are not prerequisites requiring satisfaction, but rather “interrelated considerations” that the court must balance.
The appeals court found that the pro-choice plaintiffs were more likely to prevail than the defendant state, because the holdings in Roe v. Wade and Planned Parenthood v. Casey, the two authoritative cases on the matter, support the plaintiffs' claims.  In these two cases, the Supreme Court of the United States recognized the constitutional right to seek abortion before viability.  The court established that without the injunction, the plaintiffs' patients would irreparably harmed, because the plaintiffs' constitutional rights would be violated under these two authorities cases.  Additionally, the court recognized that there was a public interest of maintaining the status quo in granting the injunction. Though the court did not affirmatively establish whether granting the injunction would irreparably harm the defendants, the court rebutted the state's claims that the state would be harmed by virtue of the court ruling not to implement a state's law.  The state argued that the court would threaten the democratic representative process by preventing the state from enacting the law through preliminary injunction.  The court, however, criticized the state's argument on the grounds that law is unconstitutional, and the state likely did not have a valid interest in implementing the law.  Despite this point of contention, the court found the injunction appropriate, because the injunction fulfilled three of the four balancing factors in the court's criteria to grant preliminary injunction regardless of the question over whether the state would be irreparably harmed.
item.category: Sixth Circuit of the United States

item.title: Can a Judge be a "Worker"? - The UK Supreme Court Gives a Landmark Answer - FOR REVIEW
item.dc:creator: ypavliuk
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court of the United Kingdom ruled on Wednesday that exclusion of judges from the whistle-blowing protection under Employment Rights Act 1996 ("the Act") was in breach of the European Convention of Human Rights. Ms. Gilham served as a district judge in England and Wales since 2006. While on the bench, she was raising concerns about governmental underfunding of the court system with the local leadership judges as well as senior officials. As a result of mistreatment following her complaints she claimed to have sustained a severe degradation in her health, resulting in psychiatric injury and a disability, which was allegedly a "detriment" under the Equality Act 2010. The Act protects "qualifying disclosures" made by workers to an employer or other responsible person. There is no doubt that for the purpose of disability discrimination a judge is a "worker", since such discrimination derives from the relevant European Union law. However, the question whether a judge can be a "worker" under the whistle-blowing provisions of the Act and, therefore, enjoy protection thereunder, remained the bone of contention before the Employment Tribunal and the Court of Appeal, both giving negative answers. In order to be considered a "worker" under the 1996 Act an individual must "work under (a) a contract of employment, or (b) any other contract, whether express or implied..." In Percy v. Board of National Mission of the Church of Scotland the House of Lords distinguished between an employee, who enters into a contract with an employer, and an office holder. Since Ms. Gilham had obvious difficulties in identifying her direct employer, the appellant side put forward the argument that a judge is an office holder under the "Crown employment". The interpretation of "Crown employment" under the Act clearly states that "employment" in this section cannot mean "employment under a contract". Therefore, despite having no contractual employment, a judge can still be a "worker". Finally, the Court moved to assess whether treatment afforded to Ms. Gilham was less favourable than that afforded to others employees, who wished to make responsible public interest disclosures, and concluded that the reason for less favourable treatment lay in the judicial status of Ms. Gilham and there was no reasonable justification to that.

item.title: TEST Court of Appeals blocks Ohio law banning abortion of fetuses with Down Syndrome
item.dc:creator: amauroni
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit affirmed the district court's preliminary injunction on a 2017 Ohio abortion law preventing abortion providers from carrying out an abortion when the decision is based on evidence that the fetus has Down Syndrome. The American Civil Liberties Union of Ohio (ACLU) brought the lawsuit on behalf of various abortion providers last year, including Preterm-Cleveland, Planned Parenthood Southwest Ohio Region, Women's Med Group Professional Corporation, Planned Parenthood of Greater Ohio, and Roslyn Kade, M.D. The complaint was filed against state officials who enacted the law to prohibit access to pre-viability abortions based on the reason behind a mother's decision to obtain one. The plaintiffs claimed the law violated a patient's privacy and liberty guaranteed under the 14th Amendment. The defendants argued that the lower court should not have granted a categorical right to pre-viability abortion, regardless of the reason, but instead should have applied a strict scrutiny review of the issue to prevent discrimination on the basis of disability. In referencing the precedents set in both Roe v. Wade and Planned Parenthood v. Casey, as well as several other cases, the 6th Circuit disagreed with the defendants, asserting that the right to pre-viability abortion is indeed categorical. To determine whether the District Court properly granted the injunction, the Court applied a four-part analysis. The first factor was the likelihood that the plaintiffs would prevail on the merits. Second, whether they would be irreparably harmed absent the injunction. Third, whether the prospect that others would be substantially harmed if the court grants the injunction. Finally, whether there was some public interest in granting the injunction. The Court determined the statute is likely unconstitutional under Roe and Casey. Explaining, "[r]egardless of whether exceptions are made for particular circumstances, a State may not prohibit any woman from making the ultimate decision to terminate her pregnancy before viability." Turning to the remaining three factors the court stated:
Because we have already concluded that there is a likelihood that the statute is unconstitutional, it is “questionable whether the [State] has any ‘valid’ interest in enforcing” it. Id. Even if the Defendants’ argument was true, however, because all three other factors weigh in favor of Plaintiffs, the district court did not abuse its discretion in granting a preliminary injunction.
Judge Alice Batchelder dissented from the three judge panel, citing a recent concurring opinion by Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, and equating the decision to permitting "eugenicist practices concerning the prenatal Down Syndrome population." However, the preliminary injunction granted by the district court was thereby upheld by the Court of Appeals, and the act is unable to be enforced while the constitutionality of the statute is reviewed. According to reports, Ohio plans to request review by the full 6th Circuit.

item.title: TEST: California becomes first state in U.S. to ban sale of animal fur product
item.dc:creator: cmaas
item.content:encoded: California became the first state in the United States to ban the sale of fur products on Saturday. The bill makes it unlawful to sell, trade, distribute, or manufacture for sale a fur product in the state. These prohibitions are added through Section 3039 and new Section 2023 of the California Fish and Game Code. Th bill defines "fur” as any animal skin or part that has hair, fleece, or fur fibers attached. “Fur product” is defined as "any article of clothing or covering for any part of the body, or any fashion accessory, including, but not limited to, handbags, shoes, slippers, hats, earmuffs, scarves, shawls, gloves, jewelry, keychains, toys or trinkets, and home accessories and decor, that is made in whole or in part of fur." The bill includes exceptions. Used fur products, fur products used to religious purposes, and fur products used for tribal,cultural, or spiritual purposes are allowed. Animal skins used to make leather; cowhide with hair attached; deerskin, sheepskin, or goatskin with hair attached; and the skins of animals preserved through taxidermy are also not included within the bill's definition of "fur product." Anyone who is exempt to the bill is required to keep records for a year of what he/she sells. Any person who violates the prohibitions will be subject to civil penalties, which will be deposited in the California Fish and Game Preservation Fund.

item.title: Federal Court affirms dismissal of Trump's attempt to block subpoena - TEST
item.dc:creator: jdougherty
item.content:encoded: The D.C. Circuit court affirmed the district court's decision in favor of the House's Oversight Committee and against President Trump in Mazars subpoena dispute on Friday. The subpoena in question was issued by the House of Representatives Committee on Oversight and Reform to Mazars USA, LLP on April 15, 2019. The subpoena requested all statements of financial condition, annual statements, periodic financial reports, and independent auditors' reports prepared, compiled, reviewed, or audited by Mazars pertaining to the Trump Organization, Trump Corporation, and the Trump Old Post Office LLC from 2011 through 2018. According to the Committee, the documents requested of Mazars will inform its investigation into whether Congress should amend or supplement current ethics-in-government laws. The court determined that the purpose of the subpoena is central to the decision. History of the House's subpoena power shows a subpoena that seeks to investigate for legislative purposes is valid. In this case, the court found several instances showing the investigation could inform legislative decision. In the opinion of the court written by Judge Tatel, the court analyzes the history of the subpoena power and the constitutional basis for it. The court decided that the Committee possesses authority under both the House Rules and the Constitution to issue the subpoena and Mazars must comply.

item.title: TEST - Circuit court upholds injunction of Ohio law banning abortion of fetuses with Down Syndrome
item.dc:creator: tgillett
item.content:encoded: In a 2-1 decision, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit upheld a district court injunction against implementing or enforcing an Ohio law that would ban abortion providers from providing abortions when the decision to abort comes from a diagnosis that the fetus has Down Syndrome. H.B. 214, signed into law in December 2017, imposed criminal penalties against any abortion provider who performed an abortion knowing that the woman sought the abortion because of a test, diagnosis, or other reason to believe that her fetus had Down Syndrome. The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit in February 2018, challenging the law on Constitutional grounds. Defendants appealed the injunction, arguing that Roe v.Wade held that the state has an interest in protecting the mother's health and in the potential life of the fetus, while H.B. 214 asserts the state's interest in preventing discrimination based on a disability, which would not fall under Roe. The circuit court found the state's attempt to sever its interest in preventing discrimination from its interest in potential life "deceptive," because the two interests are "inescapably intertwined." The court further noted that Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania v. Casey limited the state's interest in potential life to viable fetuses only and may not prohibit any woman's decision to terminate a pre-viability pregnancy. The court concluded, therefore, that H.B. 214 is in fact subject to Roe and Casey and therefore the state has no compelling interest in preventing discrimination against a pre-viable fetus with Down Syndrome.

item.title: TEST: California first U.S. state to ban sale of animal fur products
item.dc:creator: bbrown
item.content:encoded:
California has passed legislation making it the first state to ban the sale, donation or manufacturing of new animal fur products. The landmark bill, AB44, was signed into law by California Governor Gavin Newsom on Friday, along with several other laws aimed at combatting animal cruelty, including the sale of types of dead animals and banning the use of tigers and elephants in circuses.
“California is a leader when it comes to animal welfare and today that leadership includes banning the sale of fur,” said Governor Newsom. “But we are doing more than that. We are making a statement to the world that beautiful wild animals like bears and tigers have no place on trapeze wires or jumping through flames. Just YouTube the videos showing the cruel way these animals – often stripped from their mothers as babies – are trained to do dangerous tricks. It’s deeply disturbing," Newsom's signing statement. 
The law, which goes into effect January 1, 2023, defines "fur" as "any animal skin or part thereof with hair, fleece, or fur fibers attached thereto, either in its raw or processed state" and "fur product" as "any article of clothing or covering for any part of the body, or any fashion accessory, including, but not limited to, handbags, shoes, slippers, hats, earmuffs, scarves, shawls, gloves, jewelry, keychains, toys or trinkets, and home accessories and decor, that is made in whole or in part of fur." Exceptions to the law include taxidermy products, leather, cowhide and shearling as well as used fur and fur products used by Native American tribes or for a religious purpose. AB44, drafted by California assemblymember Laura Friedman, was praised by animal rights organization People or the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) as a historic bill and California a "trailblazer for animals."

item.title: Circuit Court blocks Ohio law prohibiting abortion because of Down Syndrome - TEST
item.dc:creator: jdougherty
item.content:encoded: The United States Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed on Friday a district court's decision to grant a preliminary injunction to several abortion providers alleging an Ohio law prohibiting abortions performed because an unborn child might have down syndrome. The plaintiffs, several abortion provides, alleged that that the bill, H.B. 214, unconstitutionally inhibits a woman's reason for legal pre-viability abortions. The law enacted in 2019 prohibits any person from performing an abortion "if the person has knowledge that pregnant woman is seeking the abortion, in whole or in part, because of any of the following: (1) a test result indicating Down Syndrome in an unborn child; (2) a prenatal diagnosis of Down Syndrome in an unborn child; or (3) 'any other reason to believe' that an unborn child has Down Syndrome." The law was punishable by up to 18 months in prison and the revocation of the medical license. The defendant's argue that Roe v. Wade and Planned Parenthood v. Caseydid not provide a "categorical" right to a pre-viable abortion and that the state had an "interest in preventing discrimination against person with Down Syndrome outweighs a woman's right to privacy." In the opinion by Circuit Judge Bernice Bouie Donald, the Circuit Court states that Roe and Casey States that a state's interest "may not prohibit any woman from making the ultimate decision to terminate her pregnancy before viability." The court goes on to say that the defendant's claim of discrimination cannot be separated from the state's interest in potential life and cannot override a woman's choice to terminate a pregnancy pre-viability. The Circuit Court affirmed the district court's ruling on the issue and stated that the law is likely unconstitutional.

item.title: TEST-- California becomes first state to ban the sale of fur-- PENDING
item.dc:creator: abloomberg
item.content:encoded: Governor Gavin Newsom, signed AB44 into law last Friday making California the first state to ban the sale of fur. Effective January 1, 2023, it will be "unlawful to sell, offer for sale, display for sale, trade or otherwise distribute for monetary or non-monetary consideration a fur product, as defined, in the state." The statute defines fur as "any animal skin or part thereof with hair, fleece, or fur fibers attached thereto, either in its raw or processed state." The ban on its face seems broad but a number of exceptions are included such as dog or cat fur products, animal skin converted to leather, cowhide, sheepskin or goatskins, and fur preserved through taxidermy. There are further exceptions for used fur or fur used for religious purposes. A number of California cities, including Los Angeles and San Francisco, already had fur bans in plans. In addition, a number of designers have already stopped or committed to stop using fur in their products from Giorgio Armani to H&M.  Fur bans have sparked debate between animal rights activists and environmentalist, who say that faux fur is worse for the environment. Faux fur is manufactured using petroleum products and the fibers produced are not biodegradable. The target of the ban is not the owners of fur products but the sellers. Retailers found to be selling fur in violation of the ban will be subject to fines. Californians will still be able to buy and wear fur, but soon they will have to drive to another state if they want to purchase a new fur product.

item.title: TEST -- New York Governor Andrew Cuomo signs bill closing double jeopardy loophole in relation to presidential pardons -- PENDING
item.dc:creator: msullivan
item.content:encoded: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo signed a bill on Wednesday that will close the double jeopardy loophole and allow the state to prosecute those who have been pardoned by the President of the United States. According to Article 2 of the United States Constitution, the President can pardon those convicted of federal crimes. The President does not have the power to pardon state crimes, and states have grown increasingly worried that the President can pardon crimes they otherwise would've prosecuted. Citizens of the United States are protected from being prosecuted for the same crime twice. Before the New York bill was passed, a presidential pardon for a federal crime may have barred New York from prosecuting someone for the same crime at the state level. Under the new bill, New York will be able to prosecute those who have been federally pardoned at the state level for the same crime.

item.title: Test 4
item.dc:creator: zgujral
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court of the United Kingdom has ruled that judges are entitled to "whistleblower" protections under the Employment Rights Act (ERA) of 1996. The ruling reverses a lower court decision that determined that judges did not count as "workers" under the statute. In 2011 Judge Claire Gilham raised concerns issues in the UK's court system, including budget cuts, a severely increased workload, and administrative failures. After raising her concerns Ms. Gilham was subjected to bulling, undermining by fellow judges and court staff, and that inadequate steps were taken to assist her in returning to work after taking leave for mental health issues. Ms. Gilham stated that said issues were the result of her treatment and the lack of protection she received after filing her report. In 2015, Ms. Gilham filed a two-part claim in the Employment Tribunal. Both parts depended on her falling under the definition of "worker" under the ERA. A lower court ruled that judges did not fall under the ERA. Ms. Gilham appealed. The Supreme Court ruled that due to the nature of Ms. Gilham employment, she had a work contract with the UK's government, and thus she falls under the ERA's protections for whistle blowers. The Court also agreed with Ms. Gilham that the lack of protections was a violation of her human rights. As such, Ms. Gilham's case was returned to the Employment Tribunal to be re-adjudicated with the understanding that Ms. Gilham is entitled to claim protection under the ERA.

item.title: TEST- Trump signs an executive order authorizing sanctions on Turkey
item.dc:creator: jlusamba
item.content:encoded: President Trump signed an Executive Order last Monday, which authorized sanctions on Turkey and on any person involved in Turkey's military offensive in Northeast Syria. The Order (Executive Order 13894) targets Turkey government officials and any person or entity determined by the Secretary of the Treasury to be responsible for or complicit in Turkey's recent military offensive in Syria. It authorizes sanctions even on individuals whose sole participation was to knowingly perform or facilitate financial transactions for people involved in the offensive. It authorizes sanctions in the form of a freeze on all of those individuals' assets in or under the control of the United States, a denial of visa to enter the United States , and a prohibition to any US agency, institution or person to enter into financial contracts with them. According to the order, such measures were necessary because Turkey's actions undermine the US's efforts to defeat ISIS , endanger civilians and jeopardize the stability of the region, which in turn poses a threat to the US's national security and foreign policy.

item.title: UN report on protection of civilians in armed conflict determines record high casualties in Afghanistan---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded:
The UN Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA), an impartial and independent organization focused on the protection of civilians in areas experiencing armed conflict reported and alarming high number of casualties in the country. Included in their quarterly report which included the dates January 1 to September 30, 2019, they found that between July 1 to September 30, 2019, there were in their words, "gravely concerned about the unprecedented levels of violence harming civilians." The leading cause of casualties were suicide terrorist actions and non-suicide improvised explosive devices (IEDs), these accounted for 42% of the total, with ground combat coming in second with 29% and aerial attacks responsible for 11% of deaths. The report determined that anti-government elements accounted for 62% of casualties while the Taliban themselves was responsible for 46%. The UNAMA has called repeatedly for an end to the discriminate killing of civilians and to engage with the United Nations to work for a peaceful solution to the conflict. They also urge the parties to cease the use of IED's,
"UNAMA reiterates that indiscriminate and disproportionate IED attacks are serious violations of international humanitarian law that may amount to war crimes. UNAMA repeats its call on Anti-Government Elements to immediately end the indiscriminate and disproportionate use of all IEDs, especially in areas frequented by civilians, including the use of body-borne IEDs and vehicle-borne IEDs during suicide and complex attacks."
As an independent organization, UNAMA pledges to continue providing accurate data on civilian casualties to all concerned parties in hopes this will result in the casualty rate reaching zero.

item.title: TEST New York Governor signs bill to allow the prosecution of federal pardon recipients
item.dc:creator: cstephens
item.content:encoded: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo signed a bill Wednesday permitting the prosecution of federal pardon recipients under New York law for the same offense. The amendment to the law takes effect immediately. The US Supreme Court had previously determined that recipients of federal pardons are still be subject to the laws of individual states. However, New York had a “double jeopardy” loophole, a provision in the New York code that extended federal immunity to the state level for the same offense. The bill signed Wednesday eliminates that gap. Proponents of the law argue that it is necessary given recent reports that President Trump may pardon his former campaign manager, Paul Manafort. The Eastern District of Virginia convicted Manafort of tax and bank fraud and sentenced him to over seven years in prison in March. Critics of the bill contend that it is politically motivated. Its plausible that the law could have implications in the Trump-Ukraine scandal. Rudy Giuliani, the President’s personal attorney and former mayor of New York City, has been a central figure in the impeachment inquiry. The US Attorney’s Office in Manhattan is also investigating Giuliani for possible lobbying violations. As of now, there is no indication that the State of New York is investigating Giuliani for state law violations. The White House has not issued a statement on the new law.

item.title: TEST- NY governor Andrew Cuomo signs a law allowing state prosecution despite presidential pardon
item.dc:creator: jlusamba

item.title: PRACTICE: Federal judge overturns Obamacare protection of transgender patients
item.dc:creator: spagach
item.content:encoded: On October 15th, a United States district judge for the Northern District of Texas, Wichita Falls division, overturned transgender protections enacted by Obamacare. A regulation under Obamacare ensured that providers could not deny treatment to anyone based on sex, gender identity, or termination of pregnancy. The regulation also stated that health care professionals must provide medically necessary treatment to transgender individuals. A group of Christian providers known as Franciscan Alliance, along with five other conservative states, brought the suit against the United States Department of Health and Human Services. Judge Reed O'Conner stated that this regulation infringed upon the religious freedom of the providers, as they would be required to perform abortions and transgender operations even though it would conflict with their moral beliefs. It is likely that this ruling will be appealed, but that remains to be determined. The opinion of the court can be read here.

item.title: Baltimore requests SCOTUS to deny stay in climate case---HOLD
item.dc:creator: xshi
item.content:encoded: Baltimore officials on Friday asked the U.S. Supreme Court to deny BP Plc and other oil and gas companies' attempt to stay a remand order issued by U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland. The Mayor & City Council of Baltimore sued in state court last year against BP and 25 other fossil-fuel companies for contributing to climate-related harm. BP removed to the federal district and circuit court, which granted Baltimore’s motion to remand to state court. The oil companies asked the Supreme Court on Oct. 1 for an emergency stay of the remand order until the U.S. 4th Circuit Court of Appeals weighed in on their appeal of that decision. This triggers the Federal Officer Removal statute, which allows federal agencies and officials to remove state cases to federal court. The oil companies argued that irreparable harm would result from the costs of simultaneously litigating the case in federal and state courts. Baltimore counter-argued that expensive legal proceedings are unlikely given the cases are in early stages and would result in endless requests for review by the Supreme Court.

item.title: Trudeau's Liberal party wins plurality of seats in Canadian federal election---HOLD
item.dc:creator: tdelorenzo
item.content:encoded: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's Liberal Party was able to stave off an assault from the right and maintain its position as the largest political party in Canada in the country's federal elections held on Monday. The Liberal Party entered Monday's election holding 177 of the 338 seats in Parliament, a majority that has allowed the party to control the country's agenda for the last four years without needing the support of any of the smaller parties. This majority came to an end Monday night, with the party losing 20 seats and falling below the 170 needed for a simple majority. The right-wing Conservative Party of Canada gained the bulk of these seats, increasing its share from 95 seats to 121. The Quebec nationalist Bloc Québécois also made strong gains, going from 10 to 32 seats in Parliament. Like the Liberals, the left-wing New Democratic Party also suffered losses, dropping to 24 seats from 39. The Green Party picked up a single seat and now has 3 in Parliament. With the Bloc Québécois announcing in early October that it would refuse to take part in any coalition government, it is likely that the Liberal and New Democratic parties will work together to form a left-leaning minority government. The 40-day long campaign was marred by controversy and described as one of the most vitriolic in recent history. Conservative leader Andrew Scheer accused Trudeau of racial insensitivity for appearing in blackface on multiple past occasions in addition to describing the Prime Minister as corrupt for interfering in federal investigations of a large Quebec company. Trudeau countered that Scheer was out-of-step with mainstream Canadians for his unpopular positions against same-sex marriage and legal access to abortion, as well as accusing the Conservative leader of split loyalties because of his dual USA-Canadian citizenship. The third parties did not fare much better, with four candidates for the Bloc Québécois being forced to publicly apologize after sharing anti-Islamic posts on their social media and Bloc leader Yves-François Blanchet accused of racism for calling on voters to "opt for men and women who resemble you" in a televised debate. Trudeau thanked his supporters for the victory and called for national unity following the election, saying on Twitter that "regardless of how you cast your vote, our team will work hard for all Canadians." Scheer took an adversarial position in his concession speech, saying "Mr. Trudeau, when your government falls, Conservatives will be ready and we will win."

item.title: The 9th Circuit of Appeals affirmed a preliminary injunction barring exemptions to the Women's Health Amendment to the Affordable Care Act---HOLD
item.dc:creator: zgujral
item.content:encoded: The 9th Circuit of Appeals has upheld the injunction barring the enforcement of federal agency rules that provide exemptions on moral and religious grounds to group health care plans that cover contraceptive care. In the decision filed on Monday, October 22, 2019, the 9th Circuit ruled that the plaintiffs had standing to sue, and that the final rules passed by the defendants exceeded the bounds of their statutory authority. The defendants include the US Dept. of Health and Human Services, the Dept. of Labor, and the Dept. of the Treasury. The final rules passed by the defendants provided an exemption to group health care plans that covered contraceptive care on religious and moral grounds. The defendants argued that they had the authority to pass such rules to resolve violations of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA). The Court held that those rules violated the intent and purpose of the Women's Health Amendment. The Court also held that regardless of potential violations to the RFRA, sending a self-certified form to the relevant party was likely not unduly burdensome on employers. Further, the Court held that it was not an abuse of discretion for the district court to rule that the plaintiff states would likely be harmed due to lack of an injunction. In it's opinion, the Court states that the potential irreparable economic harm is not speculative, and sufficiently supported by available documents. The defendants will likely seek a writ of certiorari following this ruling.  If so, it may be combined with Pennsylvania v Trump, a similar case for which a petition for a writ of certiorari has already been filed.

item.title: TEST ACLU challenges Minnesota voting restriction law
item.dc:creator: cstephens
item.content:encoded: The American Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit Monday, challenging the state constitutionality of a felon voting restrictions statute. The complaint, naming the Minnesota Secretary of State as the defendant, includes four convicted felons as plaintiffs. All are on supervised release and are no longer incarcerated. Under Minnesota law, all individuals who receive felony convictions immediately lose the right to vote. The central argument in the dispute relates to when the rights should be restored. A Minnesota statute declares that voting rights are restored “upon discharge”, which requires a court order or completion of a sentence. The ACLU contends that such a statute violates the state constitution. The complaint asserts, “No legitimate or rational government interest is served by refusing to restore the right to vote until discharge.” While constitutionality is the center of the lawsuit, critics express their concerns about the public policy implications of the statute. Many argue that restricting the right to is not an appropriate form of punishment in the criminal justice system. They also contend that the law is another example of the system being perpetually punitive, without giving a real second chance. It’s possible that an unconstitutional ruling could make a real impact on election day. There are over 52,000 Minnesotans who completed their felony conviction prison sentences, but still lack access to the ballot. Additionally, the law has had a particular impact on people of color. African Americans, Hispanics, and American Indians all comprise a greater percentage of the disenfranchised Minnesotans than would be expected given the racial demographics in the state. A spokesperson declined to comment on the lawsuit, but noted that the Secretary has consistently supported changing the current law to restore voting rights after leaving prison.

item.title: Second Circuit hears oral argument over President Trump's tax returns---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ywang
item.content:encoded: US Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on Wednesday heard oral argument in Trump v. Vance, an action brought by the President against the District Attorney of the New York County, who issued a subpoena to President Trump's accounting firm, seeking eight years of his personal and financial documents. Trump's counsel contended the entirety of the subpoena, calling it "an inappropriate fishing expedition, not acting in good faith." They argue that under the Nixon v. Fitzgerald ruling, a President enjoys absolute immunity from criminal investigations and indictment while he is in office, unless Congress chooses to exercise its impeachment power. With respect to third party disclosure of the President's personal records for use in grand jury investigations, the counsel argued that since the Trump organizations are fully owned by the President and have his personal financial records, they should also have such immunity. District Attorney argued that "there is no such thing as presidential immunity for tax returns", while committing to keep confidential the President's personal records and to disclose to Congress if it so requested. In addition, DA also argued that since this action is brought in Trump's personal capacity based on his private conducts, Nixon is not applicable, since it only held that the President have absolute immunity against criminal investigation based on his official conducts.

item.title: Montana residents suing for injunction against bison hunting near Yellowstone---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ssundier
item.content:encoded: A lawsuit was filed on Monday in the US District Court for the District of Columbia against the National Park Service, the Department of Agriculture, and various agency officials, alleging that these agencies have endangered local property owners and hunters by encouraging bison hunting in Beattie Gulch, Montana. Since the 1990s, state-licensed and tribal hunters have been permitted to "slaughter bison... as soon as the bison step foot across Yellowstone’s border" into Beattie Gulch. The complaint explains that hunter density has increased to a point at which it is now “common for 20-30 or more hunters to shoot simultaneously as groups of bison cross the [Yellowstone] boundary.” Because this hunting area abuts local residences, the complaint explains there is significant concern for potential accidents and deaths in the community as a result of these hunting practices. The lawsuit outlines several counts, including potential violations of the Yellowstone Management Act Amendments, the Forest Service land Management Statutes, and the National Environmental Policy act. The complaint seeks a permanent injunction against the Park Service and the Forest Service to prevent hunting of bison on federal land in Beattie Gulch and within one mile of the nearby private residences.

item.title: TEST New York legislative amendment narrows presidential pardon powers
item.dc:creator: ypavliuk
item.content:encoded: New York governor Cuomo signed the bill into law, authorizing the state to prosecute a person who has received a presidential pardon. The statutory amendment comes into force immediately and applies to future and past offenses, provided the person has not already been tried. The US Constitution authorizes president "to grant reprieves and pardons for offenses against the United States." Although presidential pardons only apply to federal crimes, New York's prior law prevented district attorneys from bringing similar state charges if a president pardons someone for a particular crime. Official statement from the governor's office explains that, "[t]he closure of this egregious loophole gives prosecutors the ability to stand up against any abuse of power, and helps ensure that no politically motivated, self-serving action is sanctioned under law." The alleged motivation behind the amendment is to prevent President Trump from pardoning his associates convicted of financial crimes and fraud. The law is narrow in scope to prevent potential challenges in courts, and applies only when presidential pardon originates a conflict of interests. The person pardoned has to be employed by the executive branch or executive office of the president; directly or indirectly work on the election campaign of the president; or be in consanguinity or affinity with the sixth degree to the president. In addition, to qualify under the exception a person is supposed to possess information material to a potential criminal or civil investigation against the president, provided that information aided the president in avoiding potential prosecution or conviction or generated knowing benefit for him. Some groups oppose change of law, claiming that it sanctions an unconstitutional bill of attainder. However, others point that it does not satisfy the three-part test, established by the Supreme Court - [1] specification of the affected persons, [2] punishment, and [3] lack of a judicial trial.

item.title: US House votes to formalize the Donald Trump impeachment inquiry
item.dc:creator: spagach
item.content:encoded: The US House voted on Thursday to formalize its impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump, who is accused of using the influence of his office to persuade Ukraine to harm his political rival, Joe Biden. The vote of 232 in favor and 196 against fell largely along party lines, with only 2 Democrats and no Republicans breaking ranks. The successful resolution was the first test of political support for impeachment, and it will see the investigation and its process formally defined. The House has not yet, but may at a future date, vote to recommend articles of impeachment against President Trump. If the House votes in favor of recommending impeachment, a trial will be held in the Senate. Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi released a statement explaining that Thursday's resolution was brought to the floor for a vote in response to claims made by the President and his allies that the House did not have the proper authorization to continue with a valid impeachment inquiry. Pelosi stated that this step is being taken "to eliminate any doubt as to whether the Trump Administration may withhold documents, prevent witness testimony, disregard duly authorized subpoenas, or continue obstructing the House of Representatives."

item.title: Amnesty verifies use of excessive force against Haiti protesters---HOLD
item.dc:creator: jcossin
item.content:encoded:
Amnesty International, on Thursday, verified evidence that Haitian police have used excessive force against protesters in Haiti in recent weeks. Amnesty alleges that police have indiscriminately used less-lethal weapons and fired live ammunition at protesters in violation of international law. The evidence takes the form of several videos, from October, showing a series of incidents in the Haitian capital of Port-au-Prince. Amnesty published three videos that they believe prove the indiscriminate use of less-lethal weapons by Haitian police. The first video shows police firing tear gas from a moving vehicle into an allegedly peaceful crowd. The second video shows police firing shotguns loaded with rubber bullets at close range into two fleeing protesters. The final video shows police beating another protester in the stomach while he flees water cannons. Amnesty also alleges that Haitian police have used live ammunition in the context of protests. The first video shows presidential guards firing combat rifles into the air directly above protesters in an attempt to force them to disperse. At least two protesters are believed to have been injured during this incident, however, attempts to verify how they were injured have been unsuccessful. The second incident shows a police officer firing a handgun directly at fleeing protesters. Amnesty believes that the protest was peaceful and that the video shows there was "no evident or immediate risk to the officer." It should, however, also be noted that not all of the Haitian protests have been peaceful and there have been many reported violent actions by groups within the demonstrations. Under international law, "the use of less lethal weapons - such as tear gas, water cannon, or rubber bullets - should be limited to specific situations after careful consideration and only when it is necessary and proportionate to a legitimate police objective." Additionally, "live ammunition is only [to be] used as a last resort and when strictly necessary to protect against an imminent threat to life or serious injury," and, "if the use of force is required to disperse violent public assemblies, it must conform to the principles of strict necessity and proportionality." Haiti has expierenced several large protests this year. The protests have focused on a variety of economic concerns most noteably a fuel crisis within the country. The underlying impetus of these protests, however, are allegations that many senior officials in the Haitian goverment, including President Jovenel Moïse, have been "implicated in the diversion of up to US$2 billion in proceeds from oil that Venezuela provided to Haiti on favorable terms." The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), on Thursday, also published a statement on the unrest in Haiti. They found that "at least 42 people have died and 86 have been injured" in the most recent round of protests. OHCHR has attributed at least 19 of the 42 deaths to government security forces. After referencing the recent death of at least one journalist and injuries sustained too many others, they stated: "We urge all actors to refrain from targeting journalists and respect the freedom of the media to report on the situation." OHCHR also acknowledged the recent allegations made against the government forces.
We welcome the launching of investigations by the General Inspectorate of the Haitian National Police into allegations of human rights violations by police and stress the need for investigations to be thorough, transparent and independent, with a view to ensuring accountability, justice and truth for victims and their families – including through judicial action.
The protests in Haiti are currently ongoing as the country continues to be haunted by its long history of civil strife. The Haitian government has yet to comment on Amnesty's allegations.

item.title: 2nd Circuit judges uphold order for release of president's tax returns---HOLD
item.dc:creator: rsalamacha
item.content:encoded:
A panel of three federal judges in the 2nd circuit of appeals upheld an order on Monday for President Trump's accountants to release his personal tax returns in accordance with a grand jury subpoena. Trump appealed a district court's order to release the tax returns arguing that he has presidential immunity from all criminal proceedings during his presidency including the grand jury subpoena. The court held that the president's accountants must comply with the grand jury subpoena despite the president's arguments. Chief Judge Katzmann explained the courts reasoning:
The President relies on what he described at oral argument as “temporary absolute presidential immunity”—he argues that he is absolutely immune from all stages of state criminal process while in office, including pre‐indictment investigation, and that the Mazars subpoena cannot be enforced in furtherance of any investigation into his activities. We have no occasion to decide today the precise contours and limitations of presidential immunity from prosecution, and we express no opinion on the applicability of any such immunity under circumstances not presented here. Instead, after reviewing historical and legal precedent, we conclude only that presidential immunity does not bar the enforcement of a state grand jury subpoena directing a third party to produce non‐privileged material, even when the subject matter under investigation pertains to the President.
This case follows from a criminal investigation in New York over the president's business dealings through the Trump Organization. The president's ex-lawyer, Michael Cohen, testified in February in the House Committee on Oversight and Reform that President Trump used the Trump Organization's funds to reimburse Cohen after paying hush money to silence those speaking on President Trump's alleged extramarital affairs. Cohen additionally alleged that the president oftentimes fabricated his tax returns for financial gain. The Manhattan district attorney obtained a grand jury subpoena for eight years of the president's tax returns in September. The president's lawyer told a Whitehouse correspondent that the legal team plans to petition the United States Supreme Court for review in light of the 2nd circuit's ruling.

item.title: TEST - Trump Unsuccessful In Tax Return Appeal
item.dc:creator: mfischer
item.content:encoded: Earlier this month the US Appeals Court for the 2nd Circuit upheld that President Trump's accounting firm must turn over the last 8 years of his tax returns. On August 1, 2019, the District Attorney of New York County served a subpoena on the Trump Organization.  The subpoena seeks a wide array of documentation, including the last 8 years of Donald Trump’s tax returns.  The purpose of the subpoena is to aid in the investigation of if Trump’s prior attorney was ordered to pay out hush money to two women.  In response, the Trump Organization provided limited documentation and no tax returns.  On August 29, 2019 the District Attorney served another subpoena to Mazars USA LLP, President Trump’s third party accountant to obtain the missing tax returns. The President’s legal team immediately appealed to the 2nd Circuit to challenge the legality of the subpoena to Mazars.  Donald Trump argued that the district court’s decision was erred, referring to precedent established in Younger v. Harris.  The President’s complaint asserts a temporary absolute presidential immunity.  Immunity would forbid the grand jury from seeking his financial records and using them to investigate his conduct that predated his presidency. The 2nd Circuit agreed with Trump that the district court erred in it’s application of Younger v Harris. However, the 2nd Circuit did ultimately affirm the final decision of the lower court. The Court held that the president cannot receive immunity for a state criminal investigation.  In a 3-0 ruling, the court AFFIRMED the district court’s decision on the immunity question, VACATED the judgment dismissing the complaint on the ground of the Younger case abstention, and REMANDED for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

item.title: TEST - ECJ Ruling Says New Retirement Rules for Polish Supreme Court Are Contrary to EU Law
item.dc:creator: ahursh
item.content:encoded: On November 5, the European Court of Justice (ECJ) held that Poland's 2017 Supreme Court reform legislation was contrary to European Union law. The new rules for judges on Poland's high court had accompanied a range of controversial reforms passed by the ruling Law and Justice Party (PiS). The ultimate retirement age for Supreme Court judges in Poland had been 70 until the new bill was enacted in 2017. Past the nominal retirement age of 67, judges could submit to the Minister of Justice their wishes to continue working up to age 70, pending a certification of good health. Under Poland's new rules, which critics saw as a power grab by the conservative political majority, judges would be forced to retire at age 65. Even judges above that age at the passage of the bill would be pushed out, and the rules for extending one's service also changed. Beyond submitting a declaration of intent and certifying one's health, under the new law, a judge's continued service was contingent on the approval of Poland's President, who could deny the extension based on no justification or criteria. The law put over 25 of Poland's 72 Supreme Court judges at risk of forced retirement, when they would be replaced by individuals picked by the current government. The European Commission sued Poland in Europe's high court, complaining that the new law threatened the independence of Poland's judiciary. The EJC delivered a win for the Commission on Tuesday, noting that a requirement of independent courts sits at the heart of the EU's charter and the common value Member States place in the rule of law. In a press release describing the decision, the court stated that the new retirement rule was "not justified by a legitimate objective and undermines the principle of the irremovability of judges, that principle being essential to their independence." The European Commission responded to the favorable holding with a statement noting that "every national court is also a European court when applying EU law. Member States must therefore ensure effective judicial protection for individuals in the fields covered by EU law." The Commission said that it "stands ready to support the Polish Government in the application of this judgment and to continue discussions on the resolution of all other outstanding issues related to the rule of law in Poland."

item.title: French Court of Appeals dismisses war crime complicity charge against LaFarge---HOLD
item.dc:creator: jlusamba
item.content:encoded: The Investigative Chamber of the Paris Court of Appeals dismissed Lafarge's indictment for complicity in war crimes and crimes against humanity yesterday. Lafarge, a French cement manufacturing company, and its CEOs were indicted on June 28, 2018 on charges of financing a terrorist enterprise, deliberately endangering people, violating its Syrian employees' rights, and being complicit in ISIS' war crimes and crimes against humanity in the region. However, yesterday, the Court of Appeals dismissed Lafarge's indictment for complicity in war crimes and in crimes against humanity but upheld the indictments for financing a terrorist enterprise, deliberately endangering people and violating employees rights. The initial criminal complaint was filed by 11 of Lafarge's Syrian subsidiary's former employees and two nonprofit organizations (Sherpa  and the European Center for Constitutional and Human Rights) in November 2016. The former employees, Sherpa and ECCHR alleged in their complaint that, in an effort to keep its cement factory in Syria open, Lafarge entered into certain commercial transactions with  the Islamic State (IS) which effectively financed IS's terrorist activities. They also alleged that Lafarge forced its employees to continue doing to work despite the intense fighting that was going on in the area and took no precautions to protect its employees. Sherpa and ECCHR intends to appeal the Court of Appeals decision to the French Supreme Court.

item.title: International Criminal Court unanimously, sentenced Bosco Ntaganda to 30 years for crimes in Congo---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded:
The International Criminal Court ("ICC"), unanimously, sentenced Bosco Ntaganda to 30 years for the crimes he committed in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Bosco Ntaganda has been detained for the past six years which will be deducted from his overall sentence. Mr. Ntaganda's sentence is the longest imposed thus far by the ICC.  Mr. Ntaganda's was on trial for war crimes and war crimes, and the Court in reaching it's judgement considered his degree of participation,  level of intent, and the amount of suffering, injury, disability and death he caused in each charged crime. The Court was also asked to consider allegations about witness interference, but these could not be not proven beyond a reasonable doubt, which is the standard required for what are considered aggravating circumstances, of which these would have been. Mr. Ntaganda was sentenced in accordance with the Rome Statute, which sets specific limits to be imposed for each of the crimes for which he was charged. The Court did consider a life sentence for Mr. Ntaganda but found that the conditions for such a sentence had not been met because of the limitations of the Rome Statute. There were further deliberations by the Court regarding forfeiture of proceeds, and or fines but the Court considered these additional penalties inappropriate under the circumstances. The following are the list of crimes for which Mr. Ntaganda was found guilty;
"murder and attempted murder as a crime against humanity and as a war crime (Counts 1 and 2): 30 years of imprisonment; intentionally directing attacks against civilians as a war crime (Count 3): 14 years of imprisonment; rape of civilians as a crime against humanity and as a war crime (Counts 4 and 5): 28 years of imprisonment; rape of children under the age of 15 incorporated into the UPC/FPLC as a war crime (Count 6): 17 years of imprisonment; sexual slavery of civilians as a crime against humanity and as a war crime (Counts 7 and 8): 12 years of imprisonment; sexual slavery of children under the age of 15 incorporated into the UPC/FPLC as a war crime (Count 9): 14 years of imprisonment; persecution as a crime against humanity (Count 10): 30 years of imprisonment; pillage as a war crime (Count 11): 12 years of imprisonment; forcible transfer of the civilian population as a crime against humanity (Count 12): 10 years of imprisonment; ordering the displacement of the civilian population as a war crime (Count 13): 8 years of imprisonment; conscripting and enlisting children under the age of 15 years into an armed group and using them to participate actively in hostilities as a war crime (Counts 14, 15, and 16): 18 years of imprisonment; intentionally directing attacks against protected objects as a war crime (Count 17): 10 years of imprisonment; and destroying the adversary’s property as a war crime (Count 18): 15 years of imprisonment."
According to the Court "The Defense and the Prosecution may appeal this Sentencing Judgment within 30 days. Reparations to victims will be addressed in due course." The sentencing hearing can be viewed here.

item.title: TEST - Federal judge blocks Trump's rule that would allow health care providers to refuse care on religious grounds
item.dc:creator: arizvi
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration proposed the "conscience rule" that would allow health care providers to refuse care to patients based on religious or moral grounds. A judicial decision in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York vacated the rule. The rule would allow health care providers to refuse care such as recommending or performing abortions, sterilizations, and assisted suicides. Under the rule, protected entities include health care employees and professionals, as well as patients. Patients would be allowed to object to certain procedures, such as screenings and mental health treatment of children. The covered entities include all entities that receive federal funds. Nineteen states, and two organizations, including Planned Parenthood, sued the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Plaintiffs challenged the rule alleging that the executive branch exceeded its authority under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). The APA governs the way federal agencies may adopt new rules and regulations. Plaintiffs alleged that the rule is "arbitrary and capricious," and breaches the APA's procedural requirements. U.S. District Court Judge Paul A. Engelmayer blocked the "conscience rule" in its entirety. Judge Engelmayer held, inter alia, that the rule violated the APA, Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the 1986 Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act. Consequently, Judge Engelmayer granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgement.

item.title: PRACTICE STORY: Federal Judge dismisses Trump's tax return lawsuit
item.dc:creator: cstephens
item.content:encoded:
A Federal Judge on Monday dismissed President Trump's tax return lawsuit against New York officials and the House Ways and Means Committee. The lawsuit attempted to restrict the committee from accessing the returns through New York's TRUST Act. The TRUST Act empowers congressional committees to request tax returns of elected officials, including the President of the United States. The New York legislature passed the law in May in an attempt to gain access to Trump's tax returns. Trump challenges the law on First Amendment grounds, arguing that New York enacted the law to discriminate against his politics and speech. Federal Judge Carl Nichols dismissed the action against New York officials on jurisdictional grounds. After providing the standard for establishing jurisdiction, the court stated:
Based on the current allegations, Mr. Trump has not met his burden of establishing personal jurisdiction over either of the New York Defendants. The Court therefore need not reach the question of proper venue.
There is speculation that Trump will appeal the ruling.

item.title: Federal judge rules US-born woman who left to join ISIS not a citizen and cannot return to US---HOLD
item.dc:creator: bbrown
item.content:encoded: A federal judge ruled Thursday that U.S. born Hoda Muthana who left the U.S. in 2014 to join ISIS is not an American citizen and cannot return with her two-year old son from Syria. The issue of Muthana's citizenship which currently bars her return to the U.S. centers on the debate over whether her father was still a diplomat at the time of her birth in 1994;  pursuant to federal regulations and as a matter of international law, children born in the U.S. to a diplomat are not given citizenship. Muthana's father, Ahmed Ali Muthana, was dismissed by the government of Yemen as a diplomat in the U.S. in June 1994, but according to statements by the State Department, the offifial notice to the U.S. Mission to the United Nations of his termination only came in February 1995, four months after his daughter's birth in October 1994. U.S. Distrcit Court Judge Reggie Walton's ruling Thursday was based on the Department of State's statement that ended Ahmed Ali Muthana's diplomatic immunity in February 1995, placing Muthana's birth in New Jersey in October 1994 in the time period of her father's time as a diplomat, thus barring her right to birthright citizenship.
